subject: Counselor Education
course_name: Family, School, and Community Partnerships in a Global Context
description: P: Admission to the Counselor Education, MS or consent of the program coordinator.      Exploration of the structure, challenges, benefits and impacts of family, school, and community partnerships for human development in domestic and global settings.

subject: Counselor Education
course_name: Integrated Behavioral Health in Rural Settings
description: P: Admission to the Counselor Education, MS or consent of the program coordinator.      Introduction to the practice of mental health counseling in rural communities using an integrated behavioral health approach. Focuses on the characteristics and concerns of diverse rural populations and the impact of utilizing integrated, culturally-appropriate, behavioral health services with rural populations.

subject: Counselor Education
course_name: Skills for Counseling Spanish Speaking Families
description: P: Admission to the Counselor Education, MS or consent of the program coordinator.      Introduction to helping strategies for mental health professionals working with Spanish speaking families. Provides an overview of Latinx communities, including culture, myths, and realities; an introduction to Spanish language, fundamental vocabulary and useful expressions for working with Spanish speakers; and culturally-appropriate strategies, including working effectively with interpreters and working with culturally and linguistically diverse populations.

subject: Counselor Education
description: P: Admission to the Counselor Education, MS or consent of program coordinator; COAD 6400  , COAD 6404  , COAD 6409  .      Application of counseling skills and knowledge, including individual counseling and consultation, in clinical mental health, school or higher education setting.

subject: Counselor Education
description: P: COAD 6409  or consent of instructor.      Seminar. Timely concerns of clients and effective strategies for intervention. Examines strategies used to help clients with topical issues.

subject: Counselor Education
description: Requires both university and field supervision. P: Admission to the Counselor Education, MS or consent of program coordinator; minimum grade of B or better in COAD 6482  .      Supervised counseling experience including direct service provision at site specific to professional specialization.

subject: Counselor Education
description: Requires both university and field supervision. P: Admission to the Counselor Education, MS or consent of program coordinator; minimum grade of B or better in COAD 6482  , COAD 6991  .      Supervised counseling experience including direct service provision at site specific to professional specialization.

subject: Counselor Education
description: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 s.h.

subject: Counselor Education
description: May be repeated. No credit may count toward degree. Students conducting thesis research may only register for this course during the summer.

subject: Counselor Education
description: P: COAD 6402  or equivalent or consent of instructor.      Explores aspects of effective career development, successful career preparation, and life-long career planning. Practical application of career theory concepts to rapidly changing world of work and futuristic trends.

subject: Counselor Education
description: P: COAD 6404  or equivalent or consent of instructor.      In-depth examination of various counseling strategies and approaches for practicing counselors. Study of selected consulting models and approaches.

subject: Counselor Education
description: P: COAD 6405  or equivalent or consent of instructor.      Supervised practicum in group counseling. Emphasis on development of counseling skills through analyzing and leading small groups. Didactic content related to experiences in group work.

subject: Counselor Education
course_name: Professional, Legal, and Ethical Issues in Counseling
description: P: Admission to the Counselor Education, MS or consent of program coordinator.       For advanced students in counseling.

subject: Counselor Education
course_name: Administration and Management of Student Affairs in Higher Education
description: P: COAD 6411  or consent of instructor.      Managing and understanding student affairs agencies, workers in those agencies, and student needs that create those agencies. Considers planning, funding, budgeting, and direction of such agencies.

subject: Counselor Education
course_name: Research Methods and Design in Counseling
description: P: Admission to the Counselor Education, MS or consent of program coordinator.       Review of methodological problems in counseling research. Development and critique of research designs. Emphasis on application of research to work of counselor.

subject: Counselor Education
description: P: Enrolled in EdS in counselor education; COAD 7404  , COAD 7405  ; or consent of instructor.      Practicum experience in supervision of counselor trainees. Establishment of supervisory relationship, critiquing of tapes, and application of supervision principles.

subject: Counselor Education
description: Review of the historical roots and continuum of medical education, instructional methods, accreditation requirements, and research of medical education.

subject: Data Science
description: May count a maximum of 3 s.h. from a combination of DASC 5501, 5502, 5503. P: Consent of instructor.      Individual study under the immediate direction of a faculty member in a selected area of advanced data science study that supplements regular curriculum.

subject: Data Science
description: May count a maximum of 3 s.h. from a combination of DASC 5501, 5502, 5503. P: Consent of instructor.      Individual study under the immediate direction of a faculty member in a selected area of advanced data science study that supplements regular curriculum.

subject: Data Science
description: May count a maximum of 3 s.h. from a combination of DASC 5501, 5502, 5503. P: Consent of instructor.      Individual study under the immediate direction of a faculty member in a selected area of advanced data science study that supplements regular curriculum.

subject: Data Science
description: First of a two-course sequence. P: Enrolled in the master of science in data science program or consent of instructor.      Essential mathematical, statistical, and computational knowledge needed for data scientists. Review of set theory, permutations and combinations, sums, functions, relations, recurrences, essence of differentiation and integration, elementary graph theory, and essential linear algebra. Other topics include conditional and joint probability, random variables and their distributions, expectation and moments, transformations and conditional expectation, inequalities and limit theorems, Markov Chains and  Markov Chain Monte Carlo, and Poisson processes.

subject: Data Science
description: Second of a two-course sequence. P: DASC 6000  or consent of instructor.      Essential mathematical, statistical, and computational knowledge needed for data scientists. Topics include Bayesian learning and probabilistic graphical models, network representations, inference, and learning.

subject: Data Science
description: P: Enrolled in the master of science in data science program or consent of instructor.      Approaches to storing, processing, retrieving, analyzing, and managing massive-scale structured and unstructured data. High-performance computing and architectures and methods for developing and querying databases for Big Data using NoSQL systems.

subject: Data Science
description: Introductory-level programming experience in any high-level programming language (e.g., Python, R, Java) is highly recommended before taking this course.  P: Enrolled in the one of the following programs: Computer Science, MS; Data Science, MS; or Software Engineering, MS; or consent of instructor.      Principles of data visualization and communication. Foundational components of visualizations, choosing the right graphic for visualization, solving visualization problems, and effective communication of the results to diverse audiences.

subject: Data Science
description: Mathematical, statistical, and computational foundations of machine learning and their application to Data Science problems. Regression, clustering, and classification as general-purpose machine learning tools. Neural network algorithms and deep learning.

subject: Adult Education
description: Uniqueness of adult as learner. Development and changes in adulthood that affect learning process.

subject: Adult Education
description: Developmental process of aging through sociological, physiological, and psychological aspects. Emphasis on overall educational implications, particularly resources and program planning related to all areas of older adult population.

subject: Adult Education

subject: Adult Education

subject: Anatomy and Cell Biology
course_name: Current Topics in Anatomy and Cell Biology
description: May be repeated more than once. P: Admission to a BSOM graduate program or consent of chair.      Read and discuss literature in selected fields relevant to anatomy. Format and subject matter may be tailored to needs of individual student or small group of students at discretion of chair, student’s advisory committee, and faculty member willing to direct readings.

subject: Anatomy and Cell Biology
course_name: Current Topics in Anatomy and Cell Biology
description: May be repeated more than once. P: Admission to a BSOM graduate program or consent of chair.      Read and discuss literature in selected fields relevant to anatomy. Format and subject matter may be tailored to needs of individual student or small group of students at discretion of chair, student’s advisory committee, and faculty member willing to direct readings.

subject: Anatomy and Cell Biology
course_name: Current Topics in Anatomy and Cell Biology
description: May be repeated more than once. P: Admission to a BSOM graduate program or consent of chair.      Read and discuss literature in selected fields relevant to anatomy. Format and subject matter may be tailored to needs of individual student or small group of students at discretion of chair, student’s advisory committee, and faculty member willing to direct readings.

subject: Anatomy and Cell Biology
description: P: Admission to the Anatomy and Cell Biology graduate program or consent of chair. Human anatomy based on systematic dissection of human body with emphasis on structure-function relationships. Pertinent human embryology and radiologic anatomy integrated topically with area of body being dissected. Relevance of different areas of anatomy and embryology to clinical procedures and/or disease processes presented by practicing clinicians.

subject: Anatomy and Cell Biology
description: MCBI 7410    P: Admission to a BSOM graduate program or consent of course director.      Foundational cornerstone for students interested in a contemporary research career. Principles of modern molecular biology as applied to the study of cell structure and function. Includes fundamentals of molecular and cellular biology of both prokaryotes and eukaryotes, and techniques used to study these problems. Emphasis on critical analysis of experimental data and experimental basis of current knowledge of cellular processes.

subject: Anatomy and Cell Biology
description: P: Admission to a BSOM graduate program or consent of chair.      Emphasis on light microscopic features of cells, tissue, and organs. Electron microscopic features of cell organelles studied to highlight functions basic to all cells. Both histological and cell biological features integrated with physiological function, pathological abnormalities, and pharmacological treatment.

subject: Anatomy and Cell Biology
description: PHLY 7730    P: Admission to a BSOM graduate program or consent of chair.      Comprehensive survey and function of human nervous system, including introduction to clinical neuroscience. Lab sessions include dissection of human brain and study of prospected specimens.

subject: Anatomy and Cell Biology
description: P: Admission to a BSOM graduate program or consent of chair.      Discuss contemporary concepts in developmental biology. Human embryological formation clearly traced to various cell and molecular biological mechanisms for clear understanding of their role, which is crucial in understanding normal, abnormal, and oncogenic development in humans.

subject: Anatomy and Cell Biology
description: Register for course for 3 semesters. P: Admission to the Anatomy and Cell Biology Graduate program or consent of chair.      Allow student to begin research activity and explore thesis research topics under guidance of scientist with ongoing research project. Student carefully guided to formulate hypothesis, design experiments, collect data, analyze data, and make conclusions so that research efforts will have high likelihood for seminar presentation, abstract/poster presentation at a national meeting, or journal publication.

subject: Anatomy and Cell Biology
description: Register for course for 4 semesters. P: Admission to the Anatomy and Cell Biology Graduate program or consent of chair.      Student will attend dept seminar series comprised of well-respect scientists describing their recent methodology and research results in current and exciting cell biological problems as related to clinical issues. Students present formal seminar in chosen cell biological area under guidance of faculty. Faculty will instruct students in scientific content, proper slide preparation, organization, basic public speaking skills, handling of audience questions, audience awareness, and stage presence.

subject: Anatomy and Cell Biology
description: BIOC 7345; BIOL 7345   P: General chemistry, organic chemistry, general biology, and general physics; or consent of instructor.      Multidisciplinary exploration of mechanism, structure, and function of motile systems essential for eukaryotic life.

subject: Anatomy and Cell Biology
description: BIOC 7365    P: ANAT 7240  or BIOC 7330  or consent of chair.      Formal instruction, critique and practice in writing a research grant proposal.

subject: Anatomy and Cell Biology

subject: Biostatistics
description: P: BIOS 1500 or consent of instructor.      Distribution of disease in human populations and factors that influence this distribution. Emphasis on leading causes of death, evaluating health research, and utilizing epidemiologic methods.

subject: Biostatistics
description: BIOS 6021   P: MATH 1065 or consent of instructor.      Applies statistical methods to health sciences. Types, organization, and display of data; elementary probability; parametric and nonparametric techniques when dealing with one or two samples (matched and independent); one way ANOVA; and simple linear regression.

subject: Biostatistics
description: BIOS 6022   P: BIOS 7021  with a grade of B or better or consent of instructor.      Continuation of BIOS 7021  . Topics include ANOVA for multi-factor designs and analysis of single degree of freedom contrasts; randomized block and repeated measures designs; nonparametric methods for standard designs; multiple linear and logistic regression; and chi-square analysis of contingency tables.

subject: Biostatistics
description: BIOS 6501   P: BIOS 7021  or equivalent with a grade of B or better or consent of instructor.      Experimental designs and their analysis. Topics include completely randomized, randomized block, Latin square, and split-unit designs; factorial treatment structures and repeated measures designs; multiple comparison procedures; tests of normality and homogeneity of variance; measures of effect size; and power considerations.

subject: Biostatistics
description: BIOS 5450   P: BIOS 7021  or equivalent with a grade of B or better or consent of instructor.      Overview of the most commonly used multivariate statistical techniques. Topics include Hotelling’s T-square, MANOVA, discriminant analysis, cluster analysis, principal components, factor analysis, canonical correlation, multidimensional scaling, and correspondence analysis.

subject: Biostatistics
description: BIOS 5500   P: BIOS 7021  or equivalent with a grade of B or better or consent of instructor.      Statistical methods requiring less restrictive assumptions (than parametric methods) about the form of the population distribution. General linear rank statistics, tests and estimation of location, dispersion, regression, and association in the nonparametric setting.

subject: Biostatistics
description: BIOS 5575   P: BIOS 7021  or equivalent with a grade of B or better or consent of instructor.      Statistical methods for time-to-event data, including censoring, hazard rates, estimation of survival curves, and methods to compare survival curves. Applications to clinical trials.

subject: Biostatistics
description: BIOS 5600   P: BIOS 7021  or equivalent with a grade of B or better or consent of instructor.      Introduction to the analysis of categorized data; rates, ratios, and proportions; relative risk and odds ratio; Cochran-Mantel- Haenszel procedure; life table methods; linear models for categorical data. Applications in demography, epidemiology, and medicine.

subject: Biostatistics
description: P: BIOS 7021  and BIOS 7022  with a grade of B or better, or consent of the instructor.      Survival analysis and generalized linear models including logistic regression and Poisson regression. Topics may be include ordinal regression and aspects of linear mixed models.

Tools include Gliffy (diagramming), PostgreSQL (database management system), Tableau (visualization), and PyCharm (Python IDE).

description: P: Admission to EdS program.      International, national, and state levels. Emphasis on contemporary educational problems. Review of educational research for possible solutions.

subject: Educational Leadership
description: For practicing administrators and supervisors. P: Admission to EdS or EdD program or consent of instructor.      In-depth study of major concepts of education law and policy and their relationship to school district organizations and administration. Emphasis on the impact of laws and policies on the areas of instruction and curriculum, human resources, management and finance, and educational equity and social justice.

subject: Educational Leadership
course_name: Special Topics Seminar in Educational Leadership
description: May be repeated with a change of topic. A maximum of 9 s.h. may count toward the degree.       Current topics in educational leadership based on student interest and current educational priorities.

subject: Educational Leadership
description: P: Consent of instructor.      Selected topics.

subject: Educational Leadership
description: P: Consent of instructor.      Selected topics.

subject: Educational Leadership
description: Completion of field study at site is required. P: Admission to EdS or EdD program or consent of instructor.      Supervised field experiences at the local, regional, and state levels. Emphasis on formulating relationships with state, district, and influential community groups that further the district’s goals of positive culture and student performance through broad community engagement with, support for, and ownership of the district vision.

subject: Educational Leadership
description: Completion of field study at site is required. P: Admission to EdS or EdD program or consent of instructor.      In-depth field experiences at the local, regional, and state levels. Emphasis on creating a climate of inquiry strategically re-imagining the district’s vision, mission, and goals to ensure that every student graduates from high school, globally competitive for work and postsecondary education and prepared for life in the 21st century.

subject: Educational Leadership
description: P: Admission to EdD in educational leadership.      Application of organizational theory in educational administration to social systems in education.

subject: Educational Leadership
course_name: Doctoral Seminar in Human Resource Development
description: P: Admission to EdD in educational leadership.      Advanced study of theory, research, and exemplary practice in developing human resources in educational organizations.

subject: Educational Leadership
description: P: Admission to EdD in educational leadership.      Formal process for developing educational policy through federal, state, and local governments. Involvement and power of elected officials, political parties, lobbyists, and media in developing policy, both formally and informally. Impact of social issues, economics, and other forces on educational policy development.

subject: Educational Leadership
course_name: Doctoral Seminar in Political and Social Issues in Educational Leadership
description: P: Admission to EdD in educational leadership.      Process through which political and social issues affect education. Analysis of some contemporary issues that affect NC.

subject: Art and Design
description: P: Graduate standing in the School of Art and Design.      Explores ideas, theories, emergent issues, and trends in art through selected readings in art and philosophy. Discussion and analysis of reading as applied to students’ personal aesthetic and studio production.

subject: Art and Design
description: 6 studio hours per week.        An introduction to the fundamental skills used in hot and cold glass working. Emphasis on safety and movement in the glass studio.

description: 6 studio hours per week.  P: ART 6501  .      Technical development using glass as a contemporary art material. Exploration of hot-glass methods that utilize multiple-part forming and assembly processes.

subject: Art and Design
description: 6 studio hours per week.  P: ART 6502  .      Self-guided study of glass art focusing on individual thematic development and creation of a cohesive body of work.

subject: Art and Design

description: P: Acceptance in MAT program.      Classroom practice in the teaching of art and discussion of procedures used.

subject: Art Education

subject: Art Education

Duties of art supervisor, philosophies of supervision as applied to art, curriculum development in art, personnel practices and staff development in art supervision, public relations, preparation of art budgets, and legal aspects of art supervision.

subject: Art Education
description: P: Admission to the Graduate School and MAEd in art program; consent of instructor.      Issues relevant to the discipline of art education will be explored through critical analysis of readings and review of contemporary methods.

subject: Art Education

subject: Elementary Education

description: P: Admission to MAEd in ELEM; or consent of instructor.      Provides advanced analysis of language arts instruction and assessment, as well as professional development and critical reflection for elementary educators.

subject: Elementary Education

description: P: Admission to MAEd in ELEM; or consent of instructor.      Recognizing and forming plans to address management problems in the elementary school.

subject: Elementary Education

subject: Elementary Education

subject: Elementary Education

subject: Elementary Education

subject: Elementary Education
description: Examines models of professional learning and the critical role of teacher leadership in designing and delivering effective professional learning opportunities.

subject: Elementary Education

subject: Elementary Education

subject: Geological Sciences
course_name: The Geologic Component of Environmental Science
description: P: Introductory GEOL course or consent of instructor.      Basic geologic knowledge and insights that support sound, rational, and science-based environmental decisions and policies in regard to land and water use. Topics include pollution abatement, clean up, and prevention; resource extraction, use, and conservation; and hazardous geologic processes.

subject: Geological Sciences

Diversity and distribution, complexity and dynamics of interacting processes and responses, origin and evolutionary history, and role of man as major modifying force.

subject: Geological Sciences
description: P: GEOL 1550, 4010, 4011; or consent of instructor.      Geology of world’s ocean basins. Impact of geophysical, geochemical, and geobiological principles on concepts of origin and evolution of ocean basins; source, transportation, and deposition of marine sediments and formation of marine stratigraphic record; and role of oceanographic processes affecting earth history such as sea level fluctuation, plate tectonics, paleogeography, and paleoclimatology.

description: Examines race, ethnicity, socioeconomic class, gender, sexual preference, and exceptionality relative to historical, philosophical, social, cultural, political, and legal issues in schools.

subject: Education
course_name: Democratic Education in the Rural South (K-12)
description: P: Enrolled in MAT program.      Examines historical and contemporary policies and practices of public education within a rural southern context to develop place-based praxis.

subject: Education
description: P: Enrolled in MAT program.      Supports teacher candidates’ development of asset-based dispositions towards students and communities. Application through strategies to integrate community in the classroom and classroom in the community, emphasizing curriculum of care. Introduces and provides application of core practices for multilingual learners through humanizing pedagogy.

subject: Education
description: Exploration of the key tenets of critical race theory (CRT) as an analytical framework to study racial inequities in education and other organizational and community contexts. Focuses on systemic forms of racism and the relationship between individual actions and institutional policies and practices. Includes an examination of the complex intersections among race, class, gender, sexual orientation, and ability.

subject: Education
description: Institutional development of public education in US with interpretation of political, philosophical, and social forces influencing this development.

subject: Education
description: Introduces curriculum design, theory, and action research to assist with knowledge, skills, and dispositions in support of reflective practitioners. Foundations, history, and research methods of action research applied to educational settings, including action inquiry as curriculum development tool. Overview of models of curriculum theory and concrete applications of curriculum development and action inquiry.

subject: Education
description: Frequency distribution, central tendency, measurements of variability, sampling and reliability, correlation, regression, prediction, and methods of applying statistics in measurement and evaluation of instructional programs.

subject: Education
description: For students entering education graduate work. Educational history, philosophy, sociology, government, and economics. Introduction of pertinent materials.

subject: Education
description: Development and use of research, research methods, applied research, basic research, methods of reasoning, fallacies in reasoning, statistical methods, thesis writing, survey research, and evaluation of research.

subject: Education
course_name: Trends and Issues in Educational Research for Practitioners
description: Recent developments in educational research and implications for educational practitioners as research consumers. Emphasis on identification, analysis, application, and evaluation of developments in literature through field-based research.

subject: Education
course_name: Advanced Seminar in Racial Equity in Education
description: P: EDUC 6001  , EDUC 6400.      Practical application of critical race theory (CRT) and related theoretical frameworks to educational, organizational, and community practices and policies. Includes the development of an action-based project to advance racial equity in specific educational, organizational, and/or community contexts.

subject: Education
description: May be taken for 1, 2, or 3 s.h., depending upon depth of topics. Class meetings may or may not be required. Hours for courses and requirements for completion arranged with instructor. Courses may be repeated for maximum of 9 s.h. P: Consent of chair.      Individualized or specialized study of problems or issues in pertinent areas of education. Variable titles and content.

subject: Education
description: May be taken for 1, 2, or 3 s.h., depending upon depth of topics. Class meetings may or may not be required. Hours for courses and requirements for completion arranged with instructor. Courses may be repeated for maximum of 9 s.h. P: Consent of chair.      Individualized or specialized study of problems or issues in pertinent areas of education. Variable titles and content.

subject: Education
description: May be taken for 1, 2, or 3 s.h., depending upon depth of topics. Class meetings may or may not be required. Hours for courses and requirements for completion arranged with instructor. Courses may be repeated for maximum of 9 s.h. P: Consent of chair.      Individualized or specialized study of problems or issues in pertinent areas of education. Variable titles and content.

subject: Education
course_name: Global Considerations in Educational Theory and Policy: Economics and Democracy
description: May not substitute for required EDUC foundations course.       Global economic forces responsible for recent educational reforms. Evaluation of impact of those forces on domestic and foreign populations. Considers future of public school role in advancing democratic citizenship and social justice.

subject: Education
description: P: EDUC 6480  or equivalent or consent of instructor.      Scientific approach to problems in education. Utilizes advanced methodological and statistical techniques leading to design and evaluation of actual projects.

subject: Education
description: May be repeated for credit. Focus on special topics in education.

subject: Kinesiology
course_name: Programming for Inclusive Fitness and Health
description: Examines the issues concerning disability awareness, inclusive facility design and legal requirements, exercise prescription and programming, and adaptation to individuals with disabilities and chronic health conditions.

subject: Kinesiology
description: P: Consent of instructor.      Examination of the relationship of physical activity across the lifespan, including youth, adults, and older adults. Relationships between physical activity and physical and mental health are explored over the lifespan for improvements in quality of life.

subject: Kinesiology
course_name: Technology, Assessment, and Differentiated Instruction in Physical Education
description: Technology and assessment strategies to support physical education instruction and assessment in K-12 settings.

subject: Kinesiology
description: History of ideas that have defined sport from ancient times to present. Emphasis on mind/body relationships, types of knowledge, and right behavior.

subject: Kinesiology
course_name: Curriculum and Instruction in Physical Education
description: Methods of physical education curriculum model delivery that integrate short and long-term planning with creative and effective teaching practices.

subject: Kinesiology
description: Pedagogical knowledge and research integrated with motor development and motor learning content for studying effective teaching practices in physical education.

subject: Kinesiology
course_name: Analysis of Teaching Practice in Physical Education
description: Teaching behavior analysis related to class management, student activity levels, skill feedback, and verbal and nonverbal interactions through the use of systematic and informal observation techniques.

subject: Kinesiology
course_name: Reflective Supervisor and Practitioner in Physical Education
description: Application of the clinical supervision model for teacher development in physical education.

subject: Kinesiology
course_name: Intercultural Issues and Content Knowledge in Physical Education
description: Current issues and trends in contemporary K-12 physical education.

subject: Kinesiology
description: P: Admission to a graduate degree program in the College of Health and Human Performance, MPH graduate program, or consent of instructor.      Examination of physical activity and its role in health status and public health, emphasizing the chronic effects of exercise.

subject: Kinesiology
course_name: Advanced Measurement and Evaluation in Kinesiology
description: Applies measurement theory to assessment techniques in exercise and sport science. Measurement research in exercise and sport science, basic statistical analyses, and practical computer applications and methods to assess test validity and reliability.

subject: Kinesiology
description: In-depth study of theories, concepts, and principles of motor skill acquisition applied to teaching, coaching, and therapeutic settings.

subject: Kinesiology
description: Analytic strategies for kinesiology data processing using MATLAB.

subject: Kinesiology
description: Theory and skills development in clinical exercise testing.

subject: Kinesiology
description: P: KINE 6205  .      Applied clinical assessment, EKG interpretation, and exercise prescription.

subject: Kinesiology
description: Individual and group study and experiences. Physiological responses to exercise. Emphasis on effects of physical training and other factors that affect physical performance.

subject: Kinesiology
description: P: KINE 6207  .      Current topics in cardiopulmonary physiology as related to clinical and basic science aspects of exercise science. Topics include cardiopulmonary anatomy and function, ECG basics and interpretation, cardiovascular pharmacology, metabolic evaluation/ assessment/programming during exercise, and other issues related to clinical exercise science.

subject: Kinesiology
description: P: KINE 6207  .      Applies basic physiological principles in prescription of exercise and administration of training programs for individuals of differing age, health status, and occupational status. Emphasis on design of safe and effective programs of physical activity. Utilizes sound principles of exercise prescription in relation to probable professional and clinical experiences.

subject: Kinesiology
description: Lab and lectures.  P: Exercise physiology or physiology course; consent of instructor.      In-depth description and theoretical constructs of procedures used in bioenergetics research and clinical settings.

subject: Kinesiology
description: P: KINE 6207  .       Examination of prescription of resistance exercise for healthy and clinical populations. Includes the identification and prescription of corrective exercises to address movement deficiencies.

subject: Kinesiology
description: EXSS 7212   P: KINE 6208  .      Clinical experience in cardiopulmonary rehabilitation and theories and rationale for diagnostic cardiopulmonary procedures.

subject: Kinesiology
course_name: Advanced Studies in Adapted Physical Activity
description: Two lecture and three field work hours per week are required.        Examines issues concerning the health and wellness of individuals with disabilities. Includes historical and contemporary viewpoints on adapted physical activity and inclusivity, the impact of policies, and the effects of physical activity participation on the quality of life.

subject: Kinesiology
description: C: KINE 6301  .    Preparation to design, conduct and report research. Emphasis on planning research, utilizing research methods, and interpreting data.

subject: Kinesiology
description: C: KINE 6300  .    Preparation to develop and write research proposals and reports.

subject: Kinesiology
course_name: Physical Activity Programs for Individuals with Developmental, Emotional, and Learning Disabilities
description: 2 lecture and 3 field work hours per week.        Developing and implementing physical activity programs designed to meet the needs of individuals with developmental, emotional, or learning disabilities in school-based and community-based settings.

subject: Kinesiology
course_name: Advanced Middle and High School Instruction in Physical Education
description: Advanced teaching theories and methodology in secondary school physical education settings that support student learning and assessment.

subject: Kinesiology
course_name: Assessment of Physical Activity and Fitness
description: Methods to assess physical activity and fitness, understanding of determinants of physical activity, and relationship of physical activity and fitness to health.

subject: Kinesiology
description: P: KINE 6300  , KINE 6301  ; or consent of instructor.      Examines relationship between psychological processes and physical activity and fitness behaviors. Primary focus on influence of social-psychological factors on physical activity participation and impact of physical activity participation on psychological outcomes.

subject: Kinesiology
description: PSYC 6445   P: Admission to a graduate program in the College of Health and Human Performance or consent of instructor.      Seminar. Theories and psychological principles that may influence sport involvement and performance. Emphasis on practical application of psychology in order to improve quality of performance and meaningfulness of participation.

subject: Kinesiology
course_name: Group Dynamics in Physical Activity and Sport
description: Examines ways to maximize performance, promote healthy behaviors, and enhance positive experiences with physical activity through understanding the structure, processes, and performance of groups and individuals within exercise and sport settings.

subject: Kinesiology
description: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 s.h.       Current research topics in exercise and sport science.

subject: Kinesiology
description: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 s.h.       Current research topics in exercise and sport science.

subject: Kinesiology
description: May be repeated. May count a maximum of 3 s.h. P: Admission into EXSS graduate program or consent of instructor.      Physical activity instruction in various settings and with diverse learners. Special attention to college and university settings. Emphasis on reflective teaching and improvement of instructional design, implementation, and evaluation.

subject: Kinesiology
description: May be repeated. May count a maximum of 3 s.h. P: Consent of instructor.      Reviews recent research in kinesiology. Emphasis on areas of adapted physical education, biomechanics, exercise physiology, pedagogy, physical activity promotion, and sport management.

subject: Kinesiology
description: May be repeated. May count a maximum of 6 s.h. P: Graduate standing in kinesiology.      New or advanced topics.

description: 2 lecture and 3 field work hours per week.        Developing and implementing physical activity programs designed to meet the needs of individuals with orthopedic, neurologic, and sensory impairments in school-based and community-based settings.

subject: Kinesiology
description: Two lecture and three lab hours per week are required.        Examines the theories, methods, practices, and program development in the aquatic environment for people with disabilities.

subject: Kinesiology
description: Students are assigned to an on- or off- campus mentor to gain fieldwork and/or research experience. Emphasis is placed on the application of theory into practice.

description: Students are assigned to an on- or off- campus mentor to gain fieldwork and/or research experience. Emphasis is placed on the application of theory into practice.

subject: Kinesiology

description: P: Current enrollment in KINE master’s or bioenergetics doctoral program.      Introductory graduate course. Case studies, readings, policy review, assignments, and discussions with guest faculty examine areas of ethical concern for researchers. Areas include scientific misconduct, conflict of interest, abusive mentoring, improper authorship practices, protection of human participants, animal subjects of research, and others.

subject: Kinesiology

subject: Kinesiology

subject: Kinesiology

subject: Kinesiology
description: EXSS 6211   P: Graduate exercise physiology or cell physiology course and consent of instructor.      Concise summary of bioenergetics using cellular and subcellular approaches. Focus on metabolic perturbations evident with exercise and disease and interactions between the two.

subject: Kinesiology
description: P: Graduate cell or systems physiology, graduate exercise physiology, or consent of instructor.      Physiology of skeletal, cardiac, and smooth muscle at cellular and whole-organ level. Topics include muscle development, detailed anatomy/physiology, structure-function relationships, nerve-muscle interactions, pathophysiology, and muscle plasticity with exercise training, disuse, aging, and damage/regeneration.

subject: Kinesiology
description: EXSS 6335   May be repeated. May count a maximum of 4 s.h. P: Consent of instructor.      Critique of current bioenergetics literature.

subject: Kinesiology
description: P: Admission to the PhD in bioenergetics and exercise science program or KINE 6207  or consent of instructor. Regulation of major physiological systems by acute and chronic exercise with an emphasis on primary research literature.

subject: Kinesiology
description: P: Master’s degree in bioenergetics or related field.      Fundamentals in teaching in area of bioenergetics, including instruction in course development, syllabus construction, lecture preparation, examination preparation, and grading. Students involved in teaching lecture and lab for EXSS 3805, Physiology of Exercise.

subject: Kinesiology
description: BIOC 8320    P: BIOC 7301  or KINE 7211  or consent of chair.      Regulation and integration of metabolism of carbohydrates, lipids, nucleic acids, and amino acids in humans, with an emphasis on primary research literature.

description: P: Admission to MLS program.      Development and functions of libraries and information centers, professional practice and ethics, and current issues and trends.

subject: Library Studies
course_name: Reference and Information Sources and Services
description: P/C: LIBS 6010  .  Introduction to library and information science search methodologies for utilizing print and online reference sources to enact information services for resolving queries in academic, public, and school libraries.

subject: Library Studies
description: LIBS 6042   P/C: LIBS 6010  .  Use of various technological resources and tools that impact contemporary libraries. Examination of standards and issues through collaboration and production.

subject: Library Studies
description: P: LIBS 6010  , LIBS 6014  .      Designing, planning, and conducting research for the library practitioner, including the analysis and synthesis of professional library literature.

subject: Library Studies
description: P: LIBS 6010  , LIBS 6014  .      Organization of information resources, including classification, cataloging (MARC), and subject headings.

subject: Library Studies
description: P: LIBS 6010  ; RP: LIBS 6014  , LIBS 6016  .     Theory and principles of management with relevant application for public, school, and academic libraries.

subject: Library Studies
description: P: LIBS 6010  , LIBS 6014  ; RP: LIBS 6019  , LIBS 6031  .     Principles and methods of selecting print and nonprint materials, intellectual freedom, and formulation of selection policies.

description: Identification and evaluation of research resources found on World Wide Web. Search strategies, copyright, and censorship.

description: P: LIBS 6010  , LIBS 6014  , LIBS 6016  , LIBS 6019  , LIBS 6026  , LIBS 6048  , LIBS 6142  .      Strategies for education, collaboration, leadership, and assessment.

subject: Library Studies
description: P: LIBS 6010  , LIBS 6014  .      Sources of information in major subject areas.

subject: Library Studies
description: Storytelling techniques and performance for varied audiences. Historical origins, story memory, and development of storytelling programs for all ages.

subject: Library Studies
description: Seminar explores various methods and resources that can be used for genealogical research, particularly in library and online settings. Includes bibliographic discovery of heritage-based resources and materials to share within a collaborative community of practice.

subject: Library Studies
description: Origin and development of the book in its various forms from earliest times to twentieth century. Evolution of library as institution.

subject: Library Studies
description: P: LIBS 6010  .      Forms, distribution, care, and use of all types of federal government publications.

subject: Library Studies

description: P: LIBS 6010  ; RP: LIBS 6016  , LIBS 6031  , LIBS 6048  .     An overview of digital libraries and the roles they play in the profession. Topics may include the influence of digital libraries, system interaction and usability, intellectual property and preservation issues.

subject: Library Studies

subject: Library Studies
description: P: LIBS 6010  , LIBS 6014  .      Conceptualizing and collaboratively planning a program of library instruction to promote information literacy, with emphasis on application in academic library settings.

subject: Library Studies

description: P: LIBS 6010  , LIBS 6014  , LIBS 6019  .      Various available resources and problems of research in library and information studies.

subject: Information and Computer Technology
description: P: ICTN 6872  .       Concepts and technologies required for cyber risk and operations management. Topics include cybersecurity risk planning and management, user and network infrastructure management, tools and techniques for detecting cyber incidents, reacting to cyber threats with appropriate tools, security operation center, and developing continuity of operations plans.

subject: Information and Computer Technology
description: P/C: ICTN 6885  .    Evaluates the tools and benefits of leveraging programmability and automation in the Enterprise Campus and WAN. Examines platforms including device-centric automation, DNA Center for the intent-based enterprise network, Software-Defined WAN, and Cisco Meraki. Also examines current ecosystem of APIs, software development toolkits, and relevant workflows together with open industry standards, tools, and APIs, such as Python, Ansible, Git, JSON/YAML, NETCONF/RESTCONF, and YANG.

subject: Information and Computer Technology

subject: Information and Computer Technology

Includes advanced features in providing reliable information infrastructure for organizations. Topics include current and future development of dynamic routing and switching protocols and current issues on IPv6 and its deployment.

subject: Information and Computer Technology

subject: Information and Computer Technology
description: An overview of the key industries considered as critical infrastructure. Students will examine the methods used to monitor and protect resources and the mitigation strategies needed to ensure critical infrastructure resiliency.

subject: Information and Computer Technology
course_name: Information Technology Risk Analysis and Management for Critical Infrastructures
description: P/C: ICTN 6890  .   Quantitative approaches to assessing cybersecurity risks for critical infrastructures and developing concrete models for assessment and management. This course covers skills that are needed by cybersecurity managers and leaders to optimize tactical and strategic decisions related to designing, planning, deploying, and operating critical infrastructures.

subject: Information and Computer Technology
course_name: Embedded Systems and Internet of Things (loT) Security
description: P/C: ICTN 6890  .   Examines the security aspects of IoT and embedded systems that are deployed in critical infrastructure systems. Includes the application of proven cybersecurity principles and approaches to the design, development, testing, and deployment of IoT and embedded systems elements in today’s complex critical infrastructure systems while understanding the constraints specific to these technologies. Topics may include communications protocols and vulnerabilities; mobile/IoT network security; security and privacy in edge computing; and device security and supply chain security considerations.

course_name: Integrative Pharmacology and Toxicology II: ​ A Molecular and Cellular Approach​
description: P/C: BIOC 7301  ; PHAR 7606  ; or consent of the chair.  Examines the molecular processes involved in the pharmaco-/toxicokinetics and pharmaco-/toxicodynamics of exogenous agents. Students develop an understanding of the basic molecular and cellular events underlying the therapeutic action of drugs used to treat disease and the toxic action of prototypical agents that humans may be exposed to in the environment.  ​

subject: Pharmacology
description: PHAR 6609   P: PHLY 7702  or BIOC 7301  or consent of chair.      History and scope of pharmacology; pharmacokinetics including the quantitative principles of uptake, distribution, biotransformation and elimination of drugs; and pharmacodynamics including dose-response relationships, and cellular mechanisms of drug actions.

subject: Pharmacology
description: P: BIOC 7301  ; PHAR 7606  , PHAR 7607  ; or consent of chair.      Fundamental mechanisms by which drugs affect physiology and biochemistry of living systems at macromolecular, cellular, organ, systemic, and multisystemic levels related to the pharmacotherapeutic actions of drugs.

subject: Pharmacology
course_name: Current Topics in Pharmacology and Toxicology
description: May be taken for 1, 2, or 3 semester hours. May be repeated for a combined maximum of 15 s.h. with a change of topic.       Allows students to explore new and emerging pharmacology and toxicology-related issues of interest.

subject: Pharmacology
description: P: Admission to graduate program in the Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology or consent of chair.      Scheduled, fixed time assignment of new graduate students to the research laboratories of various department faculty members. Introduces new students to research programs of each department faculty member, prepares them for selection of an appropriate dissertation advisor and also develops and assesses basic research skills.

subject: Pharmacology
description: PHAR 6615   May be repeated. P: PHAR 7614  ; admission to the graduate program in the Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology.      Directed research in the laboratory of the faculty member assigned for direction of preliminary studies for dissertation research.

subject: Pharmacology
course_name: Pharmacology of the Central Nervous System
description: PHAR 6640   P: BIOC 7301  or PHLY 7702  or consent of chair.      Basic neuropharmacological principles. Theories dealing with mechanisms of action of CNS drugs. Causes and treatment of major psychiatric and neurological disorders and basis of drug abuse taught through directed literature readings and class presentations and discussions.

subject: Pharmacology
description: PHAR 6660   P: PHLY 7702  or BIOC 7301  or consent of chair.       Pathophysiology and pharmacotherapeutics of cardiovascular diseases through directed literature readings, class presentations and discussions.

subject: Pharmacology
description: P: Successful completion of doctoral candidacy exam in the Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology; consent of chair.      Instruction, mentoring, and supervision in teaching of topics in pharmacology to health science, doctoral, and/or medical students.

subject: Pharmacology
description: PHAR 6670   P: PHAR 7609  ; PHAR 7610  or consent of chair.       Advanced lab techniques in biomedical research. Molecular cloning, protein methods, equilibrium binding analysis, enzyme assays, microscopy, isolated tissue preparations, anesthesia, stereotaxic surgery, and behavioral paradigms.

subject: Pharmacology
description: P: PHLY 7702  or BIOC 7301  or consent of chair.      Principles of toxicology and the mechanisms that underlie toxic effects from the subcellular to the organism level will be discovered. In addition, patterns of toxicity of specific chemicals will be discussed, as well as how those results can be employed in risk assessment.

subject: Pharmacology
description: P: PHAR 7680  or consent of instructor.      Explores the cellular and molecular mechanisms by which xenobiotics induce their toxic effects. Focus will be on epigenomic, genomic, metabolomic, proteomic, and other biochemical and molecular interactions of xenobiotics. The clinical manifestations that occur as a result of exposure to such toxicants also will be discussed.

subject: Pharmacology
description: P: College algebra; admission to a BSOM graduate program or consent of chair.      Provides working knowledge of experimental design, analysis of variance, and other techniques.

subject: Pharmacology
description: Lectures, small-group conferences, and computerassisted labs. P: BIOC 7301  ; PHLY 7702  ; or consent of chair.      Survey of pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics, adverse effects, and pharmacotherapeutic principles of drugs affecting autonomic, cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, and central nervous systems.

subject: Pharmacology
description: Lectures, small-group conferences, and clinical practicum. P: PHAR 8601  .       Survey of pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics, adverse effects, and pharmacotherapeutic principles of anesthetic, antimicrobial, antineoplastic, endocrine, and other therapeutic agents. Includes toxicology and treatment of poisonings.

description: May be repeated. May count for a maximum of 36 s.h. This course is graded S or U and is not included in meeting the cumulative B average required for graduation.

subject: Geological Sciences
description: 2 lectures per week.  P: GEOL 3300, 3301; PHYS 1250, 1260 or equivalent.      Seismology, gravity, rock magnetism, and heat flow as applied to earth. Emphasis on relationships between large scale features of earth and their geophysical characteristics. Lab introduces geophysical instrumentation, data processing, and interpretation.

description: 1 3-hour lab per week.  P: GEOL 3300, 3301; PHYS 1250, 1260 or equivalent.      Seismology, gravity, rock magnetism, and heat flow as applied to earth. Emphasis on relationships between large scale features of earth and their geophysical characteristics. Lab introduces geophysical instrumentation, data processing, and interpretation.

description: P: Graduate standing in GEOL or consent of instructor.      Selected topics of current geological interest.

subject: Geological Sciences
description: P: Graduate standing in GEOL or consent of instructor.      Selected topics of current geological interest.

subject: Geological Sciences
description: P: Consent of instructor.      Emphasis on grammatical style, syntax, and organization of manuscripts. Supplementary exercises develop skills in preparing illustrations (computer graphics, drafting, photographic techniques). Steps of publication process presented in detail.

subject: Geological Sciences
description: P: Graduate standing in GEOL or consent of instructor;  C: GEOL 6951  .    Methods for numerical analysis of geological research data. Topics include experimental design, data collection, descriptive sample statistics, univariate and multivariate populations, time-series analysis, and inferential tests of hypotheses of data related to the geological sciences.

subject: Geological Sciences
description: 3 lab hours per week.   C: GEOL 6950  .    Application of the principles of data analysis and inferential statistics to data derived from Earth science research through the use of several computer software programs.

subject: Geological Sciences
description: 3 lab hours per week.  P: Admission to CRM PhD program or consent of instructor;  C: GEOL 7002  .    Application of the fundamental concepts of geological and physical oceanographic principles of coastal systems.

subject: Geological Sciences

description: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 s.h. P: Consent of instructor.      Emerging and specialized research techniques and methodologies for coastal studies.

subject: Geological Sciences
description: May be repeated for a maximum of 9 s.h. P: Consent of instructor.      Independent study on selected topic. May include field work, lab work, directed readings, or some combination thereof.

subject: Geological Sciences
description: P: CHEM 1150, 1151, 1160, 1161; or equivalent; or consent of instructor.      Fundamental principles behind the use of stable and radioactive isotopes, techniques of measurement, and a broad spectrum of marine-related research to which these nuclides are applied.

subject: Geological Sciences
description: 2 lectures per week.  P: Consent of instructor.      Application of optical remote sensing to examinations of material transport within and between coupled land – ocean systems. Introduces image processing and analysis, integration of field measurement technologies and algorithm development. Emphasis is on the use of remote sensing as a research and decision-making tool.

subject: Geological Sciences
course_name: Remote Sensing of Coastal Environments Laboratory
description: 1 lab per week.  P: Consent of instructor.      Application of optical remote sensing to examinations of material transport within and between coupled land – ocean systems. Introduces image processing and analysis, integration of field measurement technologies and algorithm development. Emphasis is on the use of remote sensing as a research and decision-making tool.

subject: Geological Sciences
description: 3 lectures per week.  P: GEOL 5710  , GEOL 5711  ; or consent of instructor.      Principles and procedures for numerical modeling focusing on design and practical applications of groundwater models in hydrogeology.

subject: Geological Sciences
description: 1 3-hour lab per week.  P: GEOL 5710  , GEOL 5711  ; or consent of instructor.      Principles and procedures for numerical modeling focusing on design and practical applications of groundwater models in hydrogeology.

subject: Geological Sciences
description: P: GEOL 4010 or consent of instructor.      Examines processes involved in transport and deposition of sediment. Focus on fundamental principles and how they apply to active processes, recent sediment, and environmental applications.

subject: Geological Sciences
description: P: GEOL 5710  , GEOL 5711  ; or consent of instructor.      Advanced hydrologic topics with emphasis on computer applications and modeling. Evaluates steady-state and nonsteady-state models and applied aspects of hydrology related to management of water resources.

subject: Geological Sciences
description: P: GEOL 5710  , GEOL 5711  ; or consent of instructor.      Advanced hydrologic topics with emphasis on computer applications and modeling. Evaluates steady-state and nonsteady-state models and applied aspects of hydrology related to management of water resources.

subject: Geological Sciences
description: GEOL 6930   P: CHEM 1160.      Overview of life’s effects on chemistry of Earth’s surface. Examines interactions between atmosphere, land surface, and oceans. Biotic mechanisms in these habitats followed by synthesis of global cycles of biologically relevant elements (C, N, O, P, and S).

Selected readings from monographs or journals. Focus on specialized areas in which student has taken one or more courses in either baccalaureate gerontology minor or graduate gerontology certificate.

subject: Gerontology
description: Perspectives on aging issues. Topics may include: normal aging and pathology, aging program administration, aging policy development, research in gerontology, rural aging, and aging and ethnicity.

subject: Gerontology
course_name: Issues in Service Provision to Older Adults
description: Introduction to the aging services provision system, the range of services provided to older adults and their families, and the issues facing providers and clients.

subject: Gerontology Banked Courses

subject: Gerontology Banked Courses
description: Requires 130 hours per semester with an agency or organization providing institutional, community based, or in-home services to older adults.

subject: Gifted Education
description: Introduction to the nature and needs of diverse gifted and talented children for educators and leaders. Emphasizes cognitive, ethnic, cultural, economic, place, home/family, and affective characteristics of giftedness and talent.

subject: Gifted Education
course_name: Foundations of Gifted and Talented Education
description: RP: GIFT 6000  .     Foundational, conceptual, and programmatic models of gifted and talented education, including an equity-focused historical view of the field. Assessment and identification in gifted and talented education for educators and leaders.

subject: Gifted Education
course_name: Instructional Practices in Gifted and Talented Education
description: RP: GIFT 6000  .     Curriculum and instruction in gifted and talented education for educators and leaders, includes curriculum models, culturally responsive teaching, and equitable differentiation practices.

subject: Gifted Education
course_name: Creativity, Critical Thinking, and Problem Solving in Gifted and Talented Education
description: RP: GIFT 6000  , GIFT 6100  , GIFT 6200  .       Creativity, critical thinking, and problem solving through two lenses: strategies for teaching diverse gifted and talented learners; and communication, collaboration, and advocacy tools for the educator and leader.

subject: Gifted Education
course_name: Special Topics in Gifted and Talented Education: Trends in Equity and Advocacy
description: May be repeated up to six s.h. with change of topic.  RP: GIFT 6000  , GIFT 6100  , GIFT 6200  , GIFT 6300  .      In-depth exploration issues and trends in diversity and equity in gifted and talented education. Topics may include international topics in gifted and talented education; critical race theory in the context of gifted and talented education; economic inequities; student and teacher identity; and twice- or thrice-exceptionality.

subject: Graduate Studies

subject: Graduate Studies

subject: Graduate Studies
course_name: Research Ethics for a Complex World
description: P: Current enrollment in master’s or doctoral program.      Introductory graduate course. Case studies, readings, policy review, assignments, and discussions with guest faculty examine areas of ethical concern for researchers. Areas include scientific misconduct, conflict of interest, abusive mentoring, improper authorship practices, and protection of human participants, animal subjects of research, and others.

Theoretical base and appropriate education strategies for delivery of community health education programs including basic population concepts and measures; epidemiological indicators of health and social status of women and children; analysis of prevailing social policies as related to maternal and child health; and federal policies affecting children and families.

Comprehensive overview of physical aspects of diagnostic and therapeutic applications of radionuclides, radiation beams and measurements, imaging systems, and related equipment with lab activities in facility design, instrumentation essentials, quality assurance, and survey techniques.

subject: Physics

Emphasis on general topics of interest as found in current literature and particular areas of research at ECU Accelerator Laboratory.

Quality assurance, acceptance testing, and commissioning of equipment for clinical radiation therapy (linear accelerators, HDR, TLD, simulator, CT scanner).

description: P: Consent of instructor.      Advanced study of external and internal dosimetry. Assessment of dose from internal and external radiation exposure using analytic and statistical models.

subject: Physics
course_name: Clinical Rotation in Radiation Therapy Physics
description: 1 lecture and 21 practicum hours per week.  P: PHYS 6992  or RONC 6992  and consent of assistant chair for graduate studies.      Students participate in all aspects of clinical radiation therapy physics, gaining practical expertise in the major clinical applications of radiation to the treatment of disease.

subject: Physics
description: May be repeated for a maximum of 12 s.h. Equivalent of 1 classroom hour per week, per credit hour. P: Consent of assistant chair for graduate studies.      Intensive readings at the advanced PhD level in a physics field under supervision of faculty.

subject: Physics
description: May be repeated for a maximum of 12 s.h. Equivalent of 1 classroom hour per week, per credit hour. P: Consent of assistant chair for graduate studies.      Intensive readings at the advanced PhD level in a physics field under supervision of faculty.

subject: Physics
description: May be repeated for a maximum of 12 s.h. Equivalent of 1 classroom hour per week, per credit hour. P: Consent of assistant chair for graduate studies.      Intensive readings at the advanced PhD level in a physics field under supervision of faculty.

subject: Physics
description: PHYS 6910   May be repeated. P: Consent of instructor and chair.      Research on specialized topic or topics related to biomedical application of physics under supervision of faculty member.

subject: Physics
description: May be repeated. May count a maximum of 36 s.h.

subject: Physics
description: May be repeated. No credit may count toward degree. Students conducting dissertation research may only register for this course during the summer.

subject: Physiology
description: P: BIOL 1050, 1051; CHEM 1120.      Physiological principles fundamental to living tissue. All body systems studied as they relate to normal and pathological conditions in humans.

subject: Physiology
description: P: Consent of chair.      Foundation in principles of normal function of human body. Emphasis on human physiology. Basic physiological processes in health covered through lectures, conferences, demonstrations, and experimental lab sessions, with special emphasis to integrated nature of organ system function.

subject: Physiology
description: P: Admission to a BSOM graduate program or consent of chair.      Current theories of electrolyte and non-electrolyte transport processes at cellular and organ levels.

subject: Physiology
description: May be repeated. P: Admission to a BSOM graduate program or consent of chair.      Selected topics may include adrenal, reproductive, pituitary or thyroid physiology. Lectures and formal seminar presentation.

subject: Physiology
description: Advanced survey of the physiological principles underlying cell function, organelle function, organ systems, and systemic physiology.

subject: Physiology
description: RP: PHLY 7701  .      Advanced survey of physiological principles underlying organ systems and systemic physiology.

subject: Physiology
description: P: BMSC 7010  ; PHLY 7702  ; or consent of course director; RP: BMSC 7005  .     Principles of neuroscience including current research at the system, cellular, molecular, and genetic levels, and the role of the nervous system in the control of end-organ function.

subject: Physiology
description: P: ANAT 7202 or MCBI 7410  ; BIOC 7301  ; PHLY 7702  ; or equivalent level course; or consent of course director.      Advanced study of Proteogenomics as tool for elucidating functional mechanisms in whole organism. Bioinformatics as an approach to understanding genome/proteome data, and animal models for testing hypotheses on functions of specific gene products. State-of-the-art analytical and synthetic approaches to biomedical problems presented.

subject: Physiology
description: P: PHLY 7701  , PHLY 7702  ; or consent of chair or graduate program director.       Examines the key cellular mechanisms that regulate physiological functions and health-related impacts. Emphasis will be placed on developing independent and critical thinking when reviewing current literature on the topic of physiology.

subject: Physiology
description: May be repeated. P: PHLY 7702  or consent of chair.      Selected research topics.

subject: Physiology
description: May be repeated. P: Admission to a BSOM graduate program or consent of chair.      Selected topics of current interest.

subject: Physiology
description: ANAT 7215    P: Admission to a BSOM graduate program or consent of chair.      Comprehensive survey of structure and function of human nervous system, including introduction to clinical neuroscience. Lab includes dissection of human brain and study of prosected specimens.

subject: Physiology
description: P: PHLY 6700  or PHLY 7702  ; or consent of chair.      Basic principles of functional organization of somatic and special sensory systems. Emphasis on synaptic processing of sensory information.

subject: Physiology
description: May be repeated. P: Admission to a graduate program in physiology or consent of chair.      Collaborative or independent research in variety of physiology specialty areas, including research in preparation for doctoral dissertation.

subject: Physiology
description: May be repeated. P: PHLY 7702  ; or consent of chair.      Selected research topics.

subject: Physiology
description: P: PHLY 7702  , PHLY 7704  , PHLY 7705  ; or consent of chair.      Selected topics in lung mechanics, pulmonary function testing, pathophysiology, and pathogenesis.

subject: Physiology
description: May be repeated. May count for a maximum of 36 s.h. This course is graded S or U and is not included in meeting the cumulative B average required for graduation.

subject: Physiology
description: May be repeated. No credit may count toward degree. Students conducting dissertation research may only register for this course during the summer.

subject: Planning
description: HIST 5985  .   Historic preservation planning. Examines theoretical, legal, historical, and design bases of preservation planning.

subject: Planning
description: Critical analysis of urban planning process as related to future development of urban areas.

subject: Planning
description: Planning and urban design history, theories, tools and determinants of urban form.

subject: Planning
course_name: Research in Urban and Community Planning
description: P: MPH 6027  or PLAN 6150  .      Advanced course in urban and community planning involving research problems of increasing complexity.

subject: Planning
description: Detailed analysis and discussion of advanced regional planning concepts and methods.

subject: Planning
description: Overview of policies and practices that inform disaster planning. Includes the effect of governance structures, funding practices, stakeholder interventions, and socio-economic arrangements on disaster planning.

subject: Planning
description: May count maximum of 3 s.h. P: Undergraduate degree in PLAN or equivalent; 6 s.h. of graduate PLAN courses; undergraduate planning degree or its equivalent or a minimum of 12 s.h. of graduate work in planning prior to registering for an internship.      Supervised internship experience with professional planning personnel in approved agency/organization.

subject: Planning
course_name: Research in Rural and Regional Planning
description: P: MPH 6027  or PLAN 6150  .      Advanced course in rural and regional planning involving research problems of increasing complexity.

subject: Planning
description: P: Consent of advisor and instructor.      Environmental concepts and their relationship to various planning and management scenarios. Environmental issues, policies, strategies, tasks, and plans.

subject: Planning
description: Laws, plans, programs and techniques for safe and affordable housing at the national, state, regional and local levels; techniques for planning, organizing and development at the community and neighborhood levels.

subject: Planning
description: May count maximum of 3 s.h. P: Undergraduate degree in PLAN or equivalent; 6 s.h. of graduate PLAN courses; undergraduate planning degree or its equivalent or a minimum of 12 s.h. of graduate work in planning prior to registering for an internship.      Supervised internship experience with professional planning personnel in approved agency/organization.

subject: Planning

description: P: MPH 6027  or PLAN 6150  .      Advanced course in coastal and environmental planning involving research problems of increasing complexity.

subject: Planning
course_name: Administrative and Legislative Aspects of Planning
description: Advanced analysis of the legislative, administrative, and judicial bases affecting and enabling effective planning.

subject: Planning
description: An introduction to methodology, principles, concepts, and tools to be able to conduct research in urban economic development planning.

subject: Planning
description: May count maximum of 3 s.h. P: Undergraduate degree in PLAN or equivalent; 6 s.h. of graduate PLAN courses; undergraduate planning degree or its equivalent or a minimum of 12 s.h. of graduate work in planning prior to registering for an internship.      Supervised internship experience with professional planning personnel in approved agency/organization.

subject: Planning
description: Analysis of facilities planning, financial management and decision making essential in comprehensive and capital facilities planning processes.

subject: Planning
description: PLAN 5045   Frame of reference for studying natural resources for purpose of development.

subject: Planning
description: P: PLAN 6003  or consent of instructor.      Analysis and development of sustainable solutions for real world urban and suburban developments

subject: Planning
course_name: Seminar on World Architecture and Urbanism
description: Survey and critical analysis of world architectural styles and urban patterns.

subject: Planning
description: PLAN 5025   P: Consent of instructor.      Conceptual approach to planning and policy in coastal areas.

subject: Planning
description: PLAN 5065   Land use planning and regulatory techniques for achieving efficient urban form.

subject: Planning
description: Analysis of transportation planning, policy, and management problems. Emphasizes ground transport and the theoretical, policy, and practical challenges specific to multi-modal transportation planning in the US.

subject: Planning
description: GEOG 6110    Analysis of research procedures. Research objectives, literature searches, data collection design, data analysis techniques, and modes of presentation.

subject: Planning
description: GEOG 6150    Advanced statistical methods related to geography.

subject: Planning
description: GEOG 6250    Theory and techniques of environmental analysis. Environmental impact statements: what they are, how they came into being, their role in environmental decision making.

subject: Planning
course_name: Advanced Water Resources Management and Planning
description: GEOG 6270  .   Advanced investigation of spatial and temporal characteristics of water. Consideration of hydrologic, engineering, economic, and institutional aspects of water management.

subject: Planning
course_name: Computer Applications for Planning and Development
description: P: Consent of instructor.      Theories, models, and techniques for spatial data management, decision support, and design. CAD, GIS, and spatial quantitative methods for effective development and environmental planning.

subject: Planning
description: P: PLAN 6301  or consent of instructor.      Process of planning for development of sites. Environmental limitations and constraints, environmental regulations, and site design standards.

subject: Political Science
description: Most important events and characteristics of American foreign policy since World War II.

subject: Political Science
description: Overview of processes, forces, and influences involved in determining contemporary national security policy in United States. Explores historical and constitutional basis of common defense, evaluates national security policy making process, and explores forces and issues that define our national security infrastructure.

subject: Political Science
description: Aspects of international war, primarily between nation-states.

subject: Political Science
description: Introduces issues defining and characterizing terrorism. Primary emphasis given to issues in countering terrorism such as intelligence, international treaty issues, and use of military and criminal justice tools to respond to terrorism.

subject: Political Science
course_name: War, Peace and Security in the Middle East
description: Integrated study of international politics and security studies with a special focus on issues directly related to peace and security in the Middle East.

subject: Political Science
description: P: Consent of instructor.      Advanced study of selected aspects.

subject: Printmaking
description: P: ART 2010, 4640.      Independent investigation of specific problems in printmaking.
