subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: Consent of instructor.      Principles of kinesiology, joint anatomy, and tissue function. Emphasis on human movement at joint and system level.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: Enrolled in PTHE program.      Structure of human body. Lab dissection.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: Social and psychological issues related to physical and intellectual disability as related to patient care in physical therapy.

subject: Physical Therapy
course_name: Advanced Seminar in Movement Sciences and Disorders
description: May be repeated for a maximum of 9 s.h. with change of topic. P: Consent of instructor.      Directed investigation of a concentration area relative to normal or disordered human movement under the direction of a faculty mentor.

subject: Physical Therapy
course_name: Doctoral Colloquium in Movement Sciences and Disorders
description: May be repeated for a maximum of 9 s.h. with change of topic. P: Consent of instructor.      Experiences and training activities designed to facilitate application and transfer of knowledge and skills learned in the classroom environment in a manner necessary for success in academia.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: Consent of instructor.      Advanced training in the instrumentation and methodology used to analyze normal and disordered human movement performance. Emphasis on the mechanical and structural properties of musculoskeletal tissues and current issues and technology used in the rehabilitation of human movement.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: May be repeated with change of topic for a maximum of 12 s.h. P: Consent of instructor.      Mentored research activities and laboratory experiences to foster development of data management skills, perspective and experience with laboratory techniques, and a record of scholarship in an area of movement sciences and disorders.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: PTHE 8008  .      Acquisition of knowledge and skills related to care of patients with musculoskeletal problems. Focus on examination.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: Consent of instructor.      Neuroanatomy, neurophysiology, and neurology of nervous system. Introduces normal and dysfunctional motor control mechanisms.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: PTHE 8007  .      Physiological basis, indications, contraindications, and utilization of instrumentation for thermal treatment procedures and physics of sound. Emphasis on evidence-based practice regarding selection of modalities for specific medical conditions.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: PTHE 8007  .      Roles and responsibilities of the physical therapist including medical, legal, ethical and cultural dimensions, therapist-patient interaction, medical terminology, diagnostic interviewing strategies and professional issues.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: PTHE 8007  .      Survey of systems-based human physiology/pathophysiology, with an emphasis on normal human physiology and how perturbations in normal physiology are associated with disease states. Includes introductory pharmacology, pharmocodynamics and pharmacokinetics.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: PTHE 8103  .      Roles and responsibilities of the physical therapist and basic patient care skills.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: PTHE 8100  or consent of instructor.      Evidence-based integration of mechanical principles into physical therapy practice utilizing quantitative and qualitative approaches.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: PTHE 8007  .      Physics of electricity and physiological basis, indications, contraindications, and utilization of instrumentation for electrophysiological treatment procedures.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: May be repeated. 40 hours per week for 6 weeks. P: PTHE 8100  , PTHE 8101  , PTHE 8102  , PTHE 8103  , PTHE 8104  .      Introduces clinical practice through observation and supervised activity in acute care, orthopedic clinics or similar settings.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: PTHE 8100  .      Acquires knowledge and skills related to care of patients with musculoskeletal problems. Focus on treatment.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: PTHE 8101  or consent of instructor.      Neuroscience principles and mechanisms of normal and impaired movement, learning, emphasizing research and practice.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: PTHE 8101  .      Applies examination, therapeutic intervention and neuromuscular integration methods effective in identifying and treating motor control dysfunctions in adults with neurological and spinal cord injuries.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: PTHE 8302  .      Evaluation and treatment of children, emphasizing development of functional movement, clinical decision making, management of impairments, and practice in various settings.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: PTHE 8302  .      Applies advanced examination and therapeutic intervention methods effective in identifying and treating motor control dysfunctions in the neurological client, including CNS disorders, neuromuscular diseases, and vestibular disorders.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: 40 hours per week for 8 weeks. May be repeated. P: PTHE 8203  .      Supervised clinical training and experience in medical training facility. Emphasis on special program functions in inpatient or outpatient facility.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: PTHE 8300  .      Care of patients with musculoskeletal problems of the extremities and spine. Focus on advanced examination and intervention for complicated patients.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: PTHE 8200  .      Patient assessment, prescription criteria, rehabilitation goals, and treatment techniques. Functional assessment of patients prosthetic devices.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: PTHE 8104  or consent of instructor.       Physiology of muscle in health, disease, and aging.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: 40 hours per week for 8 weeks. May be repeated. PTHE 8403  . Supervised clinical experiences concentrating on specialized areas of physical therapy practice.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: PTHE 8502  .      Assessment and treatment used for cardiac, peripheral vascular, and pulmonary impairments. Analysis of physiological responses to physical rehabilitation treatment, benefits of preventative management, and value of interdisciplinary team management.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: PTHE 8503.      Impact of health care industry trends and issues on development and operations of PT services. Application of planning, organizing, marketing, managing and financing principles for clinical practice establishment and maintenance. Medico-legal, ethical, and quality control aspects of services.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: PTHE 8603  or consent of instructor.      Scientific method, research design, basic statistics, and procedures for communicating results to physical therapy professionals and integrating into evidence-based practice.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: PTHE 8503.      Advanced knowledge of the aging process and the treatment and management of the elderly client.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: PTHE 8104  or consent of instructor.      Impact of exercise and nutrition on promoting health and wellness as it relates to the practice of physical therapy.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: May count a maximum of 2 s.h. towards DPT. P: PTHE 8403  .      Integrates basic science and clinical experiences in professional practice.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: 40 hours per week for 10 weeks. May be repeated. P: PTHE 8503.      Supervised clinical experiences in long-term care facilities and specialized clinics.

subject: Physical Therapy
course_name: Advanced Concepts in Sports Physical Therapy
description: P: PTHE 8300  .      Advanced knowledge and skill in outpatient sports settings. Emphasis on evidence-based research.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: PTHE 8104  or consent of instructor.      Foundation in pathophysiology and/or rehabilitation of muscle. Emphasis on evidence-based research.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: PTHE 8300  .      Advanced techniques for evaluation of patients with lower extremity pathology, including biomechanics and instrumented gait analysis.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: PTHE 8200  .      Current amputee, prosthetic, and orthotic therapeutic interventions. Emphasis on evidence-based research.

subject: Physical Therapy
course_name: Advanced Seminar in Evidenced Based Practice
description: May be repeated. May count maximum of 6 s.h. P: Consent of instructor.      Critical analysis of advances in research in specialized areas of physical therapy practice.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: May be repeated. May count maximum of 4 s.h. P: PTHE 8203  , PTHE 8403  , PTHE 8603  .      Supervised experience in specialty clinical practice.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: May be repeated. May count maximum of 10 s.h. P: Consent of instructor.      Directed research with graduate-level faculty.

subject: Physical Therapy
course_name: Advanced Topics in Pediatric Physical Therapy
description: P: PTHE 8401  .      Advanced techniques for examination, evaluation and intervention for infants, children, and adolescents with/at risk for movement dysfunction in the pediatric population. Use of scientific evidence to aid in clinical decision-making.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: PTHE 8402  .      Advanced knowledge and skill in the evaluation and treatment of geriatric patients with balance and gait disorders. Emphasis on selected populations at high risk for falls.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: Consent of instructor.      Changes in muscle composition and mass with a focus on disease processes and therapeutic interventions.

subject: Physical Therapy
course_name: Advanced Concepts in Spine and Manual Therapy
description: P: PTHE 8300  .      Theories and techniques of spinal and extremity mobilizations, high velocity thrusts, and functional exercise interventions. Evidenced-based emphasis on spinal impairments and temporomandibular dysfunction.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: PTHE 8101  or consent of instructor.      Advances in scientific mechanisms and therapeutic interventions of pain.

subject: Physical Therapy
course_name: Measurement and Analysis of Human Movement
description: P: PTHE 8200  .      Development of skills necessary for acquisition and interpretation of human movement performance data pervasive in contemporary physical therapy literature.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: P: PTHE 8402  .      Application of advanced techniques for differential diagnosis and treatment of vestibular disorders.

subject: Physical Therapy
course_name: Pathomechanical Approach to Treatment of the Injured Runner
description: P: PTHE 8200  , PTHE 8301  .      Application of anatomy, biomechanics,functional anatomy, clinical skills, gait evaluation, and sports physical therapy to the injured running population.

subject: Physical Therapy
course_name: Service-Learning Practicum in Interprofessional Collaborative Practice
description: 90 practicum contact hours per semester.  P: Admission to a physical therapy graduate program or consent of graduate program coordinator/director.      Prepares students to provide team-based healthcare to local or global underserved or marginalized populations by exploring the tenets of service-learning, social determinants of health, and interprofessional collaborative care. Integrates reflection, and cooperative and experiential learning while providing pro bono healthcare services to local or global communities.

subject: Physical Therapy
course_name: Essential Concepts for the Sports Physical Therapist
description: One lecture hour and two lab hours per week are required.  P: Consent of instructor.      Designed to assist the entry-level physical therapy student in the acquisition of more advanced musculoskeletal examination and intervention skills by exposure to advanced topics in the prevention and treatment of athletic injuries. An emphasis will be placed on clinical evidence-based treatment decisions.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: Two lecture hours per week are required.  P: PTHE 8101  or consent of instructor.      Introduction to emerging research areas in basic and translational neuroscience, focusing on disorders of the central nervous system. Clinical correlations relevant to the practice of physical therapy will be emphasized.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: May be repeated for a maximum of 12 s.h. P: Consent of instructor.      Research and readings relevant to a candidate’s dissertation topic for qualifying examinations, for undertaking dissertation research, and to develop the prospectus for the dissertation.

subject: Physical Therapy
description: May be repeated for a maximum of 18 s.h. P: Successful completion of all pre-candidacy requirements.      Original research investigation on a significant aspect of human movement science or disorder.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
course_name: The Role of the Physician Assistant and the History, Philosophy, and Ethics of Medical Practice
description: History of medicine. Introduces medical ethics, nonclinical aspects of dependent practice, and roles of other health care providers involved in medical team approach to medical care and disease prevention. Explores different cultures and their perception of medicine, legal issues, quality assurance, and risk management. Facilitates development of realistic role identity for the physician assistant.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: First in a four course series.       Introduction of concepts necessary for professional practice, including medicolegal patient care and communication, health care policy, professional development, and public health.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: Second in a four course series.  P: PADP 6001  .       Professional practice topics introduced in PADP 6001 are expanded upon in this course for making meaningful connections associated with clinical practice. Includes concepts necessary for professional practice, engagement with community, including medicolegal patient care and communication, health care policy, professional development, public health, and quality improvement strategies.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: Third in a 4 part series P: PADP 6002  .       Concepts necessary for professional practice including medicolegal patient care and communication, health care policy, professional development, public health, and quality improvement strategies.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: Fourth in a four course series. P: PADP 6003  .       An in-depth examination of professional practice topics as students transition to clinical internships. Includes development of concepts necessary for professional practice, including medicolegal patient care and communication, health care policy, professional development, public health, and quality improvement strategies.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: Laboratory procedures used to identify pathophysiological processes and the rationale for ordering them. Interpretation of laboratory results and treatment options.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: Continuation of PADP 6010  .       Emphasis on ordering and interpreting lab tests in organ system based pathological case studies. Interpretation and ordering of electrocardiography, radiography and MRI, CT and PET scans.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: Structure of human body with virtual anatomy lab and clinical case studies.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: P: Enrolled in the PA program or consent of chair;  C: PADP 6030  , PADP 6050  .    Examination of the normal functioning of human tissue and organs, as well as their integration into specific biological systems. Selected abnormal conditions are used to demonstrate the relationships between physiology and medicine.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: Emphasis on medical problem-solving using patient management format and case studies.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: Clinically-oriented didactic and lab skills as preparation for clinical rotations and future clinical practice. Etiology, pathophysiology, clinical manifestations, and appropriate management of selected disease entities. Clinical training in lab sciences, standardized patients, and obtaining and writing history and physical exams. Enhances acquisition of skills necessary to formulate a diagnosis and treatment plan. Presents musculoskeletal, infectious disease, dermatology, and cardiology systems.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: Emphasis on patient interviewing, communication skills, and counseling skills. Proper use of instruments and techniques used in performing a thorough physical examination.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: Continuation of PADP 6200  .       Emphasis on adult physical examination.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: Continuation of PADP 6200  and PADP 6210  .       Emphasis on examination of the pediatric patient and the geriatric patient.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: Continuation of PADP 6150  .       Presents pulmonary, nephrology, neurology, endocrine, and hematology/oncology systems. Includes geriatrics and pediatrics.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: P: Consent of instructor.      Emphasis on behavioral medicine evaluation and treatment in an outpatient and inpatient setting.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: P: Consent of instructor.      Emphasis on internal medicine approach to direct care, initial care, comprehensive care and continuity of care.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: 40 clinical hours required per week. P: Successful completion of all PA didactic courses and consent of instructor.      Application of knowledge and skills in family medicine through initial, comprehensive and preventative care.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: 40 clinical hours required per week.  P: PADP 6325  and consent of instructor.      Application of knowledge and skills in family medicine through initial, comprehensive and preventative care primarily within the inpatient setting.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: P: Consent of instructor.      Emphasis on the family medicine approach to initial care, comprehensive care and preventive care.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: 40 clinical hours required per week. P: Successful completion of all PA didactic courses and consent of instructor.      Application of knowledge and skills in internal medicine to initial care, comprehensive care and preventative care primarily within the inpatient setting.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: 40 clinical hours required per week.  P: Successful completion of all PA didactic courses and consent of instructor.      Application of knowledge and skills in internal medicine to initial care, comprehensive care and preventative care primarily in the setting.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: P: Consent of instructor.      Emphasis on the surgical evaluation and treatment of patients in an inpatient and outpatient setting.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: P: Consent of instructor.      Emphasis on evaluation and management of emergency and surgical problems seen in the emergency department.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: P: Consent of instructor.      Emphasis on communication skills and relating sensitively to children and parents. Familiarization with normal growth and development, pediatric preventive medicine, and evaluation and management of common childhood illnesses.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
course_name: Women’s Health and Prenatal Care Clinical Practicum
description: P: Consent of instructor.      Emphasis on the examination of the female patient with focus on the most common, prenatal, obstetric, and gynecologic problems and their diagnostic assessment, formulation of appropriate treatment plans, utilization of preventive medicine, and health maintenance modalities.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: P: Consent of instructor.      Clinical experience with the aging population focusing on unique medical, psychosocial, environmental and cultural aspects of aging.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: May be repeated once at a different site. P: Consent of instructor.      Emphasis on evaluation and treatment of disease in an outpatient and inpatient setting outside of the United States.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: May be repeated once at a different site. P: Consent of instructor.      Emphasis on evaluation and treatment of disease in a medical and/or surgical setting of the student’s choice from selective sites.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: First in a two course series.  P: PADP 6004  .      Didactic and professional practice development as students transition to becoming licensed physician assistants.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: Second in a two course series. P: PADP 6501  .       Didactic and professional practice development as students transition to becoming licensed as physician assistants.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: C: PADP 6050  .    First of a 3 course sequence with a focus on foundational knowledge beginning with pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics and pathophysiological principles with progressive competency in the selection, interaction, physiological implications and administration of drugs, and beginning stages of clinical application.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: P: PADP 6510  ;  C: PADP 6150  .    Second in a 3 course sequence with focus on essential pharmacologic and therapeutic knowledge built upon the general principles of PADP 6510  . Follows organ systems covered in Clinical Medicine I.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: P: PADP 6520  ;  C: PADP 6250  .    Continuation of a three course sequence focusing on essential pharmacologic and therapeutic knowledge built upon the principles of PADP 6510  and PADP 6520  . Follows organ systems covered in Clinical Medicine II.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: P: Admission to MS PA program or consent of program director.      Evaluate the medical literature for evidence-based medical practice.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: Clinically-oriented didactic and lab skills related to knowledge and skills needed in emergency department and surgical arena. In-depth focus on acute and surgical conditions encountered in primary care and surgical settings. Pre-operative and post-operative care as well as surgical preparation to be properly demonstrated.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: P: Admission to MS PA program or consent of program director.       Demonstrate competence in performing patient histories, physical examinations, developing a diagnostic impression and creating evidence based treatment plans.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
course_name: Behavioral Medicine and Psychosocial Issues in Health Care
description: General survey of fundamental principles underlying human behavior. Includes physiological development, learning, memory, motivation, and social and abnormal behavior. Emphasis on improving communication skills and integrating knowledge of psychosocial principles and diagnoses with clinical situations. Development of counseling skills, ability to handle patients with stress, and death and dying issues. Covers additional content in psychiatric case studies, problem-solving methodologies, and evidence-based medicine.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: Develop critical skills necessary to identify, analyze, and resolve ethical, legal, and professional issues.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
description: Basic concepts include distribution, prevalence, causation, mode of transmission and dissemination, control, and prevention strategies used to counter significant infectious disease and occupational injuries. Investigates reportable diseases and conditions; role of state health departments in the process; and role of CDC&P in collecting and evaluating data reported by state, identifying emerging pathogens, and informing treatment community in a timely manner through such venues as the MMWR.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies
course_name: Special Topics in Physician Assistant Studies
description: P: Successful completion of all PA didactic courses and consent of program director.      Topics designed for deeper application of knowledge and critical thinking or for deeper exploration of clinical medicine, health care, or health systems to enhance understanding and academic or professional growth.

subject: Physician Assistant Studies Banked Courses
description: Pharmacological knowledge basic to assessment and management skills for advanced clinical practice. Pharmacological management of patients throughout life span with common acute and chronic health problems. Overviews of selected drug classes. description: Covert action has been an aspect of American statecraft since the War of Independence and it continues to be an important foreign policy tool used by many governments. This course explores the uses and limitations of covert action in a theoretical and historical context. Includes an overview of both Western and Soviet/ Russian approaches to covert action and of notable covert operations. It also explores the contemporary relevance of covert action in terms of counterterrorism, cyber warfare, and what has been termed ‘hybrid warfare’ or the use of non-military means for destabilizing other governments.

subject: Security Studies

subject: Speech and Hearing Sciences
description: P: For undergraduate students: CSDI major; CSDI 3020, 3050, 3105; or consent of instructor; For graduate students: Consent of instructor.      Procedures used in diagnostic and treatment of communication disorders. Topics include observation styles, task presentation and analysis, reinforcement techniques, group management, and intervention models. Multicultural communication models and supervised observation experiences in various clinical and public school settings.

description: 2 and 1/2 lecture and 1 lab hours per week.  P: Consent of instructor.      Interdisciplinary approach to augmentative communication. Emphasis on team approach, including discussion of and experience with patients who require use of augmentative communication systems. Areas of study include assessment, intervention, neuromotor management, environmental control, computer access, and funding.

description: P: Graduate standing in CSDI or consent of instructor.       Childhood language disorders from infancy to school-age period. description: P: Graduate standing in CSDI or consent of instructor.       Oral and written language learning disabilities in school-age and adolescent populations. Contemporary theories, assessment practices, and intervention techniques used in management of those with language learning disorders and/or dyslexia.

In-depth study of special voice problems as well as those more commonly encountered in clinical practice and their treatment.

subject: Speech, Language, and Hearing Sciences
description: P: Consent of instructor.      Current and historical concepts of nature and etiology of stuttering and other fluency disorders such as methodologies of assessment and treatment of children and adults, parent counseling, and research design.

Areas include scientific misconduct, conflict of interest, abusive mentoring, improper authorship practices, protection of human participants, animal subjects of research, and others.

Specific topics include measurement methods; frequency, intensity and temporal encoding; localization; and speech perception.

subject: Speech, Language, and Hearing Sciences

description: Advanced study of electronics, circuits, and instruments used in basic and applied research in the hearing and speech sciences.

subject: Microbiology and Immunology
description: P: MCBI 7410  or consent of course director.      Detailed, critical presentation of molecular structure-function relationship in stability, dynamics, and expression of genetic information of both prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells. State-of-the-art analytical and synthetic approaches to molecular genetic problems.

subject: Microbiology and Immunology
description: P: MCBI 7400  or consent of course director.      Concise presentation of immunology, immunity, and immunopathology. Immunology includes principles of induction and expression of specific immune responses. Immunochemical and cellular principles of immune responses. Immunity includes role of immune reactions in infections and cancer. Immunopathology emphasizes roles of immune system in tissue damage and disease.

subject: Microbiology and Immunology
description: P: MCBI 7401  or consent of course director.      Topics covered include basic viral structure and classification, replication, genetics, pathogenesis, viral vectors, emerging viruses, and antiviral strategies and vaccines. Current and emerging issues in virology covered by reading and discussing most recent scientific literature.

subject: Microbiology and Immunology
description: May be repeated. May count maximum of 5 s.h. Microbiology and immunology students required to register each fall and spring semester while pre-candidates. subject: Music Education
course_name: Methods, Materials, and Pedagogy in Music Education
description: Instructional techniques, methods, materials, pedagogy, and diversity in music education through critical analysis and review of contemporary methods.

subject: Music Education
description: Historical development of music offerings at college level. Comparison of curriculum patterns in major divisions of collegiate music offerings. Relationship of music curricula to general education and professional subject areas.

subject: Music Education
description: Seminar on teaching techniques and challenges in music instruction.

subject: Music Education
description: Research into specific problems in some phase of music education.

subject: Music Education
description: Research into new problem in music education or continuation of problem first begun in MUSC 6927  that merits additional time and research.

subject: Music Education
course_name: Curriculum Issues and Trends in Music Education
description: May be repeated for maximum of 6 s.h.       Contemporary philosophies and objectives of music education in public education. Scope and sequence of K-12 music curriculum. Trends and developments of evaluative criteria.

subject: Music Education
description: Written research project with oral presentation.

subject: Music History and Literature
description: P: MUSC or ANTH major with consent of instructor.      Theories, methods, techniques, and fundamental concepts used in study of non-Western and primitive music.

subject: Music History and Literature
course_name: Folk and Indigenous Music of the Americas
description: Ethnic music of the Americas surveyed with particular attention to society, culture, and tradition.

subject: Music History and Literature
description: Sub-Saharan African music surveyed in the context of African society and culture.

subject: Music History and Literature
course_name: Early Music in the West: to 1600

subject: Music History and Literature

description: P: MUSC 2166 or consent of instructor.      Comprehensive overview from ethnomusicological perspective. Vernacular musics of Spanish- and Portugese-speaking cultures and their influence on art-music composers of twentieth century.

subject: Music History and Literature

description: P:  Senior/graduate standing; undergraduate survey of music history.      History with concentration on literature of major composers.

subject: Music History and Literature
description: MUSC 5667 (Sacred Music).   Recommended that MUSC 5667, MUSC 5677  be taken in sequence. P: MUSC 2416 or consent of instructor.      Historical survey of organ literature from earliest manuscripts through music of J. S. Bach in first term. From J. S. Bach to present in second term. Basic principles of organ construction and style. Emphasis on relationship between organ and its repertoire throughout centuries.

subject: Music History and Literature
description: MUSC 5677 (Sacred Music).   Recommended that MUSC 5667  , MUSC 5677 be taken in sequence. P: MUSC 2416 or consent of instructor.      Historical survey of organ literature from earliest manuscripts through music of J. S. Bach in first term. From J. S. Bach to present in second term. Basic principles of organ construction and style. Emphasis on relationship between organ and its repertoire throughout centuries.

subject: Music History and Literature
description: Recommended that MUSC 5737, MUSC 5747 be taken in sequence.       Literature for piano in relation to contemporary pedagogical use. Intermediate through advanced-level literature from Renaissance through Beethoven and Schubert.

subject: Music History and Literature

description: Recommended that MUSC 5737  , MUSC 5747 be taken in sequence.       Literature for piano in relation to contemporary pedagogical use. Intermediate through advanced-level literature from Chopin and Schumann to present.

subject: Music History and Literature
description: Comprehensive survey of solo literature for lute and guitar from Renaissance to twentieth century.

subject: Music History and Literature
description: P: MUSC 2416 or consent of instructor.      Original and secondary sources on performance practices from Renaissance to present. Development of instruments and comparison of notated music with actual performance practices.

subject: Music History and Literature
description: P: MUSC 2416 or consent of instructor.      The critical examination of musical performance based on historical perspective and primary sources.

subject: Music History and Literature
description: Historical and stylistic survey and critical evaluation of choral literature for use with school, community, and sacred choirs.

subject: Music History and Literature
description: Historical and stylistic survey and critical evaluation of choral literature for use with school, community, and sacred choirs.

subject: Music History and Literature
description: Chamber music, band, wind, and percussion literature for all phases of instrumental instruction.

subject: Music History and Literature
description: MUSC 5406   Detailed consideration of analytical and historiographic issues in a variety of representative musical genres from ca. 1600-1750.

subject: Music History and Literature
course_name: Music of the Classic Era and Enlightenment
description: MUSC 5416   Detailed consideration of analytical and historiographic issues in a variety of representative musical genres from 1720 to 1820, including works of precursors and acknowledged proponents of Classic style (Haydn, Mozart, Beethoven). Exploration of the relationship of this music to Enlightenment figures such as Rousseau and Goethe.

subject: Music History and Literature
description: MUSC 5426   Detailed consideration of analytical and historiographic issues in a variety of representative musical genres of the 19th century, including developments in symphonic forms, instrumental and vocal chamber music, and opera, from Schubert to Debussy.

subject: Music History and Literature
course_name: Music of the Modern and Postmodern Eras
description: MUSC 5436   Detailed consideration of central analytical, historiographic, and philosophical issues in music of the 20th and 21st centuries, focusing primarily on post-tonal developments in traditional genres as well as crossovers with vernacular, non-western, and popular influences.

subject: Music History and Literature

subject: Music History and Literature

subject: Music History and Literature

subject: Music History and Literature

subject: Music History and Literature
description: Music history with concentration on vocal literature of major composers.

subject: Music History and Literature
description: Examination of the nature and value of music through the discipline of aesthetics, as exemplified by such figures as Aristotle, Kant and Adorno, through various modes of music criticism.

subject: Music History and Literature
description: History and development of keyboard music. Emphasis on styles and forms in eighteenth, nineteenth, and twentieth centuries.

description: P: MUSC 5887  or MUSC 5897  or consent of chair.      Advanced study of performance practice issues in music from the Middle Ages to the present.

Models of music therapy practice in traditional and innovative treatment settings. Regulatory, fiscal, legal, ethical, administrative, curricular, and accreditation issues will be addressed.

subject: Neuroscience
description: NEUR 5000   P: Consent of instructor.      Introduces cellular mechanisms and molecular basis of neuron and glial function and interaction. Topics include membrane trafficking, action potentials, receptors, and signal transduction, gene transcription factors, neuroimmunology, and developmental neuroscience.

Topics include basic neuroanatomy; computational neuroscience, learning and memory; sensory and motor systems, neural basis of affective behavior, consciousness and cognitive neuroscience, neural plasticity, and brain lateralization and language.

subject: Neuroscience

Emphasis on the molecular and cellular mechanisms of neuronal cells and unique specific systems, particularly sensory, movement, as well as behavioral development and aging.

subject: Radiation Oncology
description: PHYS 6718    P: Consent of chair.      Production, application, and measurement of electromagnetic radiation and high energy particle beams in therapeutic practice. Emphasis on conceptual, instrumental, and methodological aspects of therapeutic radiology.

subject: Radiation Oncology
description: PHYS 6992    P: PHYS 6718  or RONC 6718  .      Radiation dose calculation and measurement of high energy photon and electron beams, high and low dose rate brachytherapy sources in clinical radiation therapy, cavity theory in ion chamber calibrations of photon and electron beams. Quality assurance, acceptance testing and commissioning of equipment for clinical radiation therapy (linear accelerators, HDR, TLD, simulator, CT scanner).

subject: Radiation Oncology
description: PHYS 6993    P: PHYS 6992  or RONC 6992  .      Practical patient dosimetry problems in radiation oncology. Irregular field calculations, two-and three dimensional treatment planning, isodose distribution, high and low dose rate brachytherapy planning for intracavitary, and interstitial radioactive sources.

subject: Radiation Oncology
description: RONC 5370   P: BIOL 1100, 1101, 1200, 1201; or consent of instructor.      Biological effects resulting from interactions of radiation and matter for scientifically, technically, and medically oriented students.

subject: Reading
description: May not be taken by students who have had READ 3204.       Beginning reading process. Understanding of essential skills. Early detection and remediation of possible reading problems.

subject: Reading
description: May not be taken by students who have completed READ 3205. P: READ 3204 or READ 5312  .       Guidance in designing reading programs on basis of individual and group presentations. Practicum experience in guiding individual and group student activities in reading instructional program.

subject: Reading
course_name: Word Study: Phonics, Spelling, and Vocabulary Instruction
description: Examination of word knowledge and its role in K-12 literacy instruction. Knowledge of phonics, spelling, word development, and vocabulary instruction using a generative approach.

subject: Reading
course_name: Adolescent Literacy in the Content Areas
description: May receive credit for only one of READ 3990, 5317.       Investigation of research-based instructional approaches to improve adolescent learning strategies related to the different dimensions of literacy (e.g., reading, writing, speaking listening, viewing) across content area courses.

subject: Reading
course_name: Learning to Read: From Novice to Expert
description: A comprehensive review of the science of learning to read, from children’s earliest alphabetic skills, to fluent word recognition, to the skilled comprehension of text that is characteristic of expert readers.

subject: Reading
description: Part 1 of literacy development and instruction across grades K-12. An exploration of developmentally responsive, culturally responsive, balanced literacy instruction, integrated across reading, writing, and language. Includes examination of recent research, with a focus on knowledge and strategies known to accelerate literacy learning and development for K-5 students, with specific strategies for accommodating English learners.

subject: Reading
description: RP: READ 6102  .     Part 2 of literacy development and Instruction across grades K-12. An exploration of developmentally responsive, culturally responsive, balanced literacy instruction, integrated across reading, writing, and language, Includes examination of recent research, with a focus on various literacy knowledge and strategies known to accelerate literacy learning and development for 6-12 students, with specific strategies for accommodating English learners.

subject: Reading
course_name: Assessment and Evaluation in Literacy Education
description: RP: READ 6101  .     Investigation of how assessment is used to measure literacy achievement, interpret results, and inform literacy instruction. Understand, select, and use appropriate assessment tools to screen, diagnose, and measure student literacy achievement, inform instruction and evaluate interventions, participate in professional learning experiences; explain assessment results and advocate for appropriate literacy practices to relevant stakeholders.

subject: Reading
course_name: Diversity and Equity in Literacy Instruction
description: Investigation of foundational theories about diverse learners and key components of culturally responsive instruction and equity in education with a focus on inclusive classrooms, literacy identities, and high quality children’s and young adult literature.

subject: Reading
course_name: Using Literacy Assessment for Instructional Intervention
description: P: READ 6101  ; RP: READ 6104  .     Engagement in authentic, hands-on intervention-based practicum experiences with students that focus on literacy processes, content knowledge, assessment, and evidence-based instructional strategies.

subject: Reading
description: RP: READ 6101  , READ 6104  .     Examination of literacy research, policy, and promising practices for purposes of designing, implementing, and assessing professional learning experiences for educators and/or education stakeholders.

subject: Reading

subject: Recreation Sciences

subject: Recreation Sciences
description: An exploration of the application of ecotourism principles to visitor and natural resource management of parks. Includes an examination of the principles of attracting and managing visitors in a sustainable manner and the role of parks in global conservation.

subject: Recreation Sciences
description: Strategies for planning and developing tourism as a recreational industry within communities and regions. Introduction to foundational concepts of entrepreneurship, the role of entrepreneurship in community development, and the fundamental concepts, principles, and approaches to operating tourism and recreation businesses in both public and private natural resource settings.

subject: Recreation Sciences
description: Examination of the development of the field of conservation psychology, including psychological constructs that influence behaviors, and theories that explain the relationship of these constructs to conservation outcomes. Strategies to foster a connection to nature, influence responses to the natural and built environments, and cultivate sustainability through the adoption of conservation behaviors will also be examined.

subject: Recreation Sciences

subject: Recreation Sciences

subject: Recreation Sciences

subject: Recreation Sciences

subject: Recreational Therapy

Topics may include typical patterns of leisure behavior in later life; the relationship between leisure activities and physical, cognitive, social, and emotional health; and aspects of planning leisure activity programs for the aging population.

description: Recommended to be taken in sequence.   C: MUSC 6597.    2-semester internship for skill development under direct supervision of site supervisor and university advisor.

subject: Nursing
description: May be repeated. May count a maximum of 6 s.h. P: Consent of instructor.      Independent exploration of area(s) of interest in nursing science.

Pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics, adverse effects and pharmacotherapeutic principles of drugs affecting the autonomic, antimicrobial, antineoplastic, endocrine, GI, cardiovascular systems and other therapeutic agents.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Advanced Pharmacology for Nurse Anesthetists II
description: P: Admission to the DNP nurse anesthesia specialty area or permission of the nurse anesthesia program director; NURS 8814  , NURS 8817  ; PTHE 8008  ;  C: NURS 8269  , NURS 8811  , NURS 8819  .    Pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics, adverse effects, and pharmacotherapeutic principles of drugs mitigating inflammation and pain and those affecting the cardiovascular, respiratory, renal and central nervous systems.

Explores clinical applications of drugs and techniques used during anesthesia delivery for planned and emergent cases.

subject: Nursing
description: P: Admission to the DNP nurse anesthesia specialty area or permission of the nurse anesthesia program director; NURS 8277  , NURS 8818  , NURS 8822  , NURS 8824  ;  C: NURS 8823  , NURS 8893  .    Focuses on a variety of professional issues including the history of nurse anesthesia, professional socialization and participation, roles of the nurse anesthetist and the American Association of Nurse Anesthetists, regulation of nurse anesthesia practice, standards of care, scope of practice, practice settings and employment options, reimbursement, quality assessment, the legal system, medical ethics and chemical dependency, patient safety, and infection control and standard precautions.

subject: Nursing

Application of principles of physics, general, organic and biochemistry and their interrelationships to the understanding of basic physiologic and pharmacologic principles in anesthesia.

subject: Nursing

Focuses on preparation of the anesthetizing environment; patient assessment and physiologic monitoring; anesthetic techniques, interventions and associated equipment; pharmacologic agents; communication and documentation; and anesthesia care plan construction and evaluation.

subject: Nursing

In-depth study of the principles of anesthesia practice with focus on tenets of anesthesia care for increasingly advanced surgical and radiological procedures on patients across the lifespan with complex medical histories and the principles of safety and cultural sensitivity.

subject: Nursing

description: P: Admission to the DNP nurse anesthesia specialty area or permission of the nurse anesthesia program director; NURS 8272  , NURS 8274  , NURS 8815  , NURS 8820  , NURS 8821  ;  C: NURS 8274  , NURS 8821  .    In depth study of the principles of anesthesia practice with focus on the tenets of anesthesia care for increasingly advanced surgical and radiological procedures on patients with complex medical histories, with an emphasis on cardiovascular, neuro and trauma cases, and the principles of safety and cultural sensitivity.

subject: Nursing
description: P: Admission to the DNP nurse anesthesia specialty area or permission of the nurse anesthesia program director; NURS 8805  , NURS 8810  , NURS 8813  ;  C: NURS 8814  ; PTHE 8008  .    Correlation of didactic knowledge of gross anatomy and national wellness initiatives with clinical application and personal wellness goals.

subject: Nursing
description: P: Admission to the DNP nurse anesthesia specialty area or permission of the nurse anesthesia program director; NURS 8274  , NURS 8816  , NURS 8821  ;  C: NURS 8277  , NURS 8822  , NURS 8824  .    Integration of theory with practice by critically analyzing current anesthetic literature, and anesthetic management of selected cases in a focused simulation experience. Selected research is used to support patient care decisions. National wellness initiatives are correlated with personal wellness goals.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Clinical Practicum in Nurse Anesthesia I
description: 8 clinical hours per week. P: Admission to the DNP nurse anesthesia specialty area or permission of the nurse anesthesia program director; NURS 8814  , NURS 8817  ; PTHE 8008  ;  C: NURS 8269  , NURS 8811  .    Application of didactic learning through preparation, planning, and implementation of general and regional anesthetics. Use of previously developed skills and progress from basic anesthesia management to administration of anesthesia for patients with complex medical histories and for advanced procedures. Procedural knowledge, including communication and interprofessional collaboration, is reinforced by simulation instruction. Journal articles and case reports are presented, critically analyzed and discussed in weekly clinical conferences and monthly department conferences. Specialty clinical rotations include cardiovascular, neurological, obstetrics, pediatrics, and regional anesthesia. Clinical rotations are continued through university designated break periods.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Clinical Practicum in Nurse Anesthesia II
description: 32 clinical hours per week.  P: Admission to the DNP nurse anesthesia specialty area or permission of the nurse anesthesia program director; NURS 8269  , NURS 8806  , NURS 8811  , NURS 8819  ;  C: NURS 8272  , NURS 8815  .    Application of didactic learning through preparation, planning, and implementation of general and regional anesthetics. Use of previously developed skills and progress from basic anesthesia management to administration of anesthesia for patients with complex medical histories and for advanced procedures. Procedural knowledge, including communication and interprofessional collaboration, is reinforced by simulation instruction. Journal articles and case reports are presented, critically analyzed and discussed in weekly clinical conferences and monthly department conferences. Specialty clinical rotations include cardiovascular, neurological, obstetrics, pediatrics, and regional anesthesia. Clinical rotations are continued through university designated break periods.

subject: Mathematics Education
description: MATH 6223   May be repeated once with change of topic. May not count toward mathematics requirement for MAEd. P: Consent of instructor.      Exhaustive study of current topic in mathematics education.

subject: Mathematics Education
description: MATH 6226   Each course may be repeated once with change of topic. May not count toward mathematics requirement for MAEd. P: Consent of instructor.      Mathematics content and information necessary for service as leader in public school mathematics education.

subject: Mathematics Education
description: MATH 6227   Each course may be repeated once with change of topic. May not count toward mathematics requirement for MAEd. P: Consent of instructor.      Mathematics content and information necessary for service as leader in public school mathematics education.

subject: Mathematics Education
description: MATH 6228   Each course may be repeated once with change of topic. May not count toward mathematics requirement for MAEd. P: Consent of instructor.      Mathematics content and information necessary for service as leader in public school mathematics education.

subject: Mathematics Education
description: MATH 6229   May not count toward mathematics requirement for MAEd. P: Consent of instructor.      Mathematics content and information necessary for service as leader in public school mathematics education.

subject: Mathematics Education
course_name: Diagnostic Approach to Teaching Elementary Mathematics I
description: MATH 6261   May not count toward mathematics requirement for MATH MA. May count as elective in other programs. P: MATE 5251  or MATE 5263  or consent of instructor.      Methods of diagnosing and prescribing for individual difficulties in mathematics at elementary and secondary school levels. Applies principles and techniques during clinical work.

subject: Mathematics Education
description: Technology applications in grades 6-12 based on national recommendations, research, and issues pertaining to equity and access.

subject: Mathematics Education
description: MATH 6320   May not count toward mathematics requirement for MAEd. P: Certification in elementary education at undergraduate level.      Current research, materials, methods, and curricula for teaching and learning elementary school mathematics.

subject: Mathematics Education
description: MATH 6321   May not count toward mathematics requirement for MAEd. P: Certification in mathematics at middle grades undergraduate level.      Current research, materials, methods, and curricula for teaching and learning middle-level mathematics.

subject: Mathematics Education
course_name: Issues and Trends in Mathematics Education
description: MATH 6323   May not count toward mathematics requirement for MAEd. P: Graduate standing and certification in secondary mathematics.      Current research, materials, methods, and curricula for teaching and learning high school mathematics.

subject: Mathematics Education
description: Rational numbers, proportional reasoning, and linear relations as tools to explore mathematical relationships in grades 6-8.

subject: Mathematics Education
description: Analysis of middle school student work using the van Hiele model to examine relationships of shape, size, symmetry, and transformations in two- and three- dimensional space.

subject: Mathematics Education
course_name: Data Analysis and Probability in the Middle Grades
description: Data analysis, probability concepts, and pedagogical issues for middle grade teachers.

subject: Mathematics Education
description: Key issues in teaching and learning measurement as it supports other mathematical strands.

subject: Mathematics Education
description: Current mathematical learning theory and research as it pertains to algebra taught from a problem-solving, student-centered perspective.

subject: Mathematics Education
description: Historical and contemporary models applied to real-world situations to demonstrate the power and limitations of modeling.

subject: Mathematics Education
description: Research project, portfolio modeled on the National Board Professional Teaching Standards, or equivalent project.

subject: Mathematics
course_name: Logic for Mathematics and Computer Science
description: CSCI 5002    P: CSCI 2405 or MATH 2300 or MATH 3256 or PHIL 3580 or equivalent.      Methods of mathematical logic that have important applications in mathematics and computer science.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: MATH 3263 or consent of instructor.      Topics in elementary and algebraic number theory such as properties of integers, Diophantine equations, congruences, quadratic and other residues, and algebraic integers.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: MATH 2228 or MATH 2283 or MATH 3308 or MATH 6802  ; or equivalent; or consent of instructor.      Topics include correlation, estimation and testing in multiple regression, residual analysis, diagnostics, multicollinearity, model building, analysis of variance, and use of statistical software.

subject: Mathematics
description: May not be taken for credit by those having completed MATH 6011  . P: MATH 3263 or consent of instructor.      Continuation of development of topics begun in MATH 3263. Normal subgroups, factor groups, homomorphism, rings, ideals, quotient rings, and fields.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: MATH 2153 or 2173, and MATH 2300; or consent of instructor.      Axioms of real number system, completeness, sequences, infinite series, power series, continuity, uniform continuity, differentiation, Riemann integral, Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: MATH 3256; and MATH 4101 or MATH 5101  ; or consent of instructor.      Mathematical analysis of functions of several real variables. Includes limits, continuity, differentiation, and integration of multivariable functions.

subject: Mathematics
description: May not be taken for credit by those having completed MATH 6111  . P: MATH 2173.      Complex numbers, analytic functions, mapping by elementary functions, integrals, residues, and poles.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: MATH 2173.      Numerical analysis of problems with one independent variable. Solution of nonlinear equations in one unknown, interpolation and approximation of functions of one variable, numerical integration, and numerical differentiation and optimization.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: MATH 2173, MATH 3256, MATH 3331; or consent of instructor.       Numerical analysis of problems with several independent variables. Numerical solution of ordinary differential equations, systems of linear equations, numerical linear algebra and matrix algebra, systems of nonlinear equations, and systems of ordinary differential equations.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: MATH 2173; 3307 or MATH 5801  .      Mathematical models; linear programming; simplex method, with applications to optimization; duality theorem; project planning and control problems; and elementary game theory.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: MATH 2173, 3256; 3307 or 5801.      Introduces stochastic processes. Queuing theory with applications to inventory theory and forecasting, Poisson and Markov processes, reliability simulation, decision analysis, integer programming, and nonlinear programming.

subject: Mathematics
description: PHYS 5311  .   P: MATH 4331; PHYS 2360; or consent of instructor.      Mathematical methods important in physics. Emphasis on application. Functions of complex variables, ordinary and partial differential equations, integrals and integral transforms, and special functions.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: MATH 2300 or consent of instructor.      Fundamental concepts and structural development of mathematics. Non-Euclidean geometries, logic, Boolean algebra, and set theory. Construction of complex number systems. Transfinite cardinal numbers and study of relations and functions. Topics developed axiomatically.

subject: Mathematics
description: Individual work with student.

subject: Mathematics
description: C: MATH 2172 or consent of instructor.    History of mathematics from antiquity to present. Emphasis on study of significant problems which prompted development of new math. Uses computer resources and library for research of topics and solutions.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: MATH 2173 or consent of instructor.      Topics include operations with complex numbers, De Moivre’s Theorem, properties of polynomial functions, roots of general cubic and quartic equations, methods of determining roots of equations of higher degree, and methods of approximating roots.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: MATH 3308 or consent of instructor.       An introduction to computing targeted at statistics students with minimal programming knowledge. Emphasis on core ideas of programming illustrated through key statistical topics including (but not limited to) methods of moments, maximum likelihood estimations, linear models, nonlinear models, basic optimizations, graphics, and simulations.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: MATH 2173 or 3307.      Axioms of probability, random variables and expectations, discrete and continuous distributions, moment generating functions, functions of random variables, Central Limit Theorem, and applications.

subject: Mathematics
description: May not be taken for credit after MATH 5101  or MATH 6011  . P: Consent of director of graduate studies or advisor. Introduces advanced mathematics for beginning graduate students.      Covers various proof methods and provides rigorous introduction to topics in logic, number theory, abstract algebra, and analysis.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: MATH 2300, MATH 3256; or consent of instructor.      Abstract vector spaces, subspaces, linear transformations, matrix representations of linear transformations, eigenvalues, eigenvectors, diagonalization, inner product spaces, Jordan canonical form.

subject: Mathematics
course_name: Introduction to Sampling and Experimental Design
description: P: MATH 2228 or MATH 2283 or MATH 3308 or MATH 6802  ; or consent of instructor.      Fundamental principles and statistical analysis of survey sampling and experimental design. Data sources and types, survey design, sampling schemes.  Randomization, control, replication, blocking, factorial designs.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: MATH 3263 or equivalent      Basic algebraic structures. Groups, rings, modules, integral domains, and fields.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: MATH 6011  .      Basic algebraic structures. Groups, rings, modules, integral domains, and fields.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: MATH 5021  .      Advanced topics in algebraic and analytic number theory.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: MATH 3307 or consent of instructor.      Single-period mathematical risk theory is covered, including approaches to modeling and measuring (insurance) risks. Topics include (univariate) distribution theory: exponential dispersion models, elliptical distributions, (a,b,k) class, heavy-tailedness; risk measurement: value-at-risk, expected shortfall, coherency; policy modifications: deductibles, (co)insurance, limits. Students are prepared to take the Society of Actuaries Exam P “Probability” and Exam C “Construction and Evaluation of Actuarial Models.”

subject: Mathematics
description: P: MATH 5102  or consent of instructor.       Analytic functions, mapping of functions, differentiation and integration, power series, and residues.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: MATH 6111  or consent of instructor.       Integral functions, infinite products, Mittag-Leffler expansion, maximum modulus theorem, convex functions, the Schwarz Christoffel transformation, analytic continuation, Riemann surfaces, and selected topics in functions of a complex variable.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: MATH 4101 or MATH 5101  or consent of instructor.      Study of functions of one real variable and convergence of sequences and series of functions: functions of bounded variation, measures, measurable sets, measurable functions, convergence almost everywhere, absolutely continuous functions, Lebesgue integration, differentiation, and the Fundamental Theorem of the Calculus.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: MATH 6121  or consent of instructor.      Lebesgue spaces and associated inequalities, measures in Rn, measure spaces and the associated theory of integration and differentiation; the Radon-Nikodym Theorem with applications to probability and statistics.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: MATH 2300 or consent of instructor.      Structure of graphs, trees, connectivity, Eulerian and Hamiltonian graphs, planar graphs, graph colorings, matchings, independence, and domination.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: Consent of instructor.      Curricula and methods of teaching mathematics to adults in colleges and technical schools.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: MATH 2172, MATH 3307; or consent of instructor.      A comprehensive introduction of the mathematical interest theory. Topics include time value of money, annuities, loan repayment, bond, and valuation of derivative securities. Prepares the student for the Society of Actuaries Exam FM “Financial Mathematics”, and MFE “Models for Financial Economics”.

subject: Mathematics
course_name: Introduction to Partial Differential Equations I
description: P: MATH 3331 or consent of instructor.      Linear and nonlinear partial differential equations of the first order with emphasis on formal aspects of these equations. Use of partial differential equations in analysis, geometry, and physical sciences is considered where appropriate.

subject: Mathematics
course_name: Introduction to Partial Differential Equations II
description: P: MATH 6401  or consent of instructor.      Nonlinear partial differential equations of the second order and higher orders. Certain theoretical aspects of partial differential equations and a limited amount of Fourier Series, Fourier transforms, Laplace transforms, and boundary value problems are included.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: MATH 3331 or consent of instructor      Existence, uniqueness, and technique of solutions to first and second order differential equations are considered. Bases for linear equations, stability, and series solutions about an ordinary point are considered.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: MATH 6411  or consent of instructor.      Autonomous systems, series solutions about a regular singular point, and Sturm-Liouville Systems are examined.

subject: Mathematics
description: May be repeated for credit with change of topic. P: Consent of instructor.      Selected topics of current interest.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: Consent of instructor.      Infinite series beyond advanced calculus level.

subject: Mathematics
description: May not count toward mathematics requirement for MATH MA. P: Consent of instructor.      Axiomatic development of probability from set operations viewpoint. Use of probability measures.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: MATH 5101  .      Metric spaces and basic point-set topology, open sets, closed sets, connectedness, compactness, and limit points.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: MATH 3307 or MATH 5801  ; consent of instructor.      Estimation and hypothesis testing from both classical and Bayesian points of view. Use of t, F, and chi-squared distributions. Least squares procedures.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: MATH 3256, MATH 5801  .      Topics include general linear model, regression models, design models, estimation of parameters, theory of least squares, and testing general linear hypotheses.

subject: Mathematics
description: P: MATH 3307 or MATH 4801 or MATH 5801  or consent of instructor.       Fundamental theory and models of stochastic processes. Topics include Markov chains and their limiting behavior and applications, Poisson processes, birth and death processes, and Gaussian processes.

subject: Mathematics
description: May be repeated. May count maximum of 6 s.h.

subject: Mathematics
description: May be repeated. No credit may count toward degree. Students conducting thesis research may only register for this course during the summer.

subject: Mechanical Engineering
description: P: Graduate status; C or better in ENGR 2050 and MATH 2154 or MATH 4331; or consent of instructor.      Solving engineering problems using numerical methods and software. Study and implementation of truncation and round-off error, root finding, optimization, linear and polynomial regression, interpolation, splines, numerical integration, numerical differentiation, solution of linear simultaneous equations, and solution of ordinary differential equations.

subject: Mechanical Engineering
description: BIME 5600    Two lecture hours and two lab hours per week are required.  P: Graduate status or consent of instructor.      Key practical knowledge of measurement and data processing approaches in engineering.  Data acquisition theory, instrumentation, sensors, nondestructive evaluation, data reduction, statistical and uncertainty analysis. Experience in designing, performing, and reporting experiments on mechanical and thermal systems.

subject: Mechanical Engineering
description: P: Graduate status in mechanical engineering or consent of program director.      Development and use of engineering research, research methods, applied research, basic research, statistical methods, thesis writing, and evaluation of research.

subject: Mechanical Engineering
course_name: Finite Element Analysis of Solids and Fluids
description: BIME 6100    P: Admission to the Mechanical Engineering, MS or consent of program director.      Basic concepts of the theory of the finite element method. Applications in solid mechanics, fluid-flows, fluid-structure interactions, heat transfer, steady-state and transient problems. Use of a general finite element computer program.

subject: Mechanical Engineering
description: P: Admission to the MS in mechanical engineering program or consent of program director.      Design methodology and analysis of thermal systems using principles of thermodynamics, fluid mechanics and heat transfer.

subject: Mechanical Engineering
description: P: Admission to the MS in mechanical engineering program or consent of program director.      General principles and applications of equilibrium thermodynamics. Second law analysis of energy systems. Thermodynamic relations, equations of state, properties of single and multiphase systems. Elementary statistical thermodynamics. Fundamentals of nonequilibrium thermodynamics.

subject: Mechanical Engineering
description: P: Admission to the MS in mechanical engineering program or consent of program director.      Conversion principles and technology behind various renewable energy sources. Issues involved in the integration of various renewable energy sources and their economics for heat, power and transportation needs.

subject: Mechanical Engineering
description: P: Admission to the MS in mechanical engineering program or consent of program director.      Basic topics in mechanics of solids including stress and strain, torsion of a circular shaft and beam bending. Application of principles to selected topics of solid mechanics. Application of modern software in solution of problems.

subject: Mechanical Engineering
description: P: Admission to the MS in mechanical engineering program or consent of program director.      Development and application of design methods that result in cost-effective and timely product manufacture. Concept and parametric product design refinements evaluated with respect to alternative manufacturing and assembly processes. Contemporary tools used in engineering design and manufacture.

subject: Mechanical Engineering
description: P: Admission to the MS in mechanical engineering program or consent of program director.      Free and forced vibrations of single-degree and multi-degree of freedom systems under a variety of time dependent loads. Numerical integration, time history analysis, and modal analysis of multi-degree of freedom systems.

subject: Mechanical Engineering
description: P: Admission to the MS in mechanical engineering program or consent of program director.      Mechanical behavior of fiber-reinforced composite materials. Topics include anisotropic stress-strain relationships, failure theories, stress analysis of laminated plates and shells, manufacturing methods, and applications.

subject: Mechanical Engineering
description: P: Admission to the MS in mechanical engineering program or consent of program director.      General solution of elasticity. Fundamentals of the theory of deformation and theory of stress. Two and three-dimensional equations of elasticity. Plane theory of elasticity in Cartesian and polar coordinate systems.

subject: Mechanical Engineering
description: P: Admission to the MS in mechanical engineering program or consent of program director.      Heat and mass transfer in biological systems at multiple scales (molecular, cellular and tissue), with specific focus on the applications of biopreservation and thermal therapies.

subject: Mechanical Engineering
description: P: Admission to the MS in mechanical engineering program or consent of program director.      Selected advanced topics in mechanical engineering. Content varies.

subject: Mechanical Engineering
description: May be repeated. May count a maximum of 6 s.h.

subject: Medical Humanities
course_name: History of Public Health in the Modern West
description: P: Graduate standing.      History of the rise of organized public health systems in the West with emphasis on the contribution such understanding can make to contemporary practices, policies, and priorities.

subject: Medical Humanities
description: Identifies philosophical, moral, political, legal, and social issues associated with scientific research. Explores relationship between moral, legal, professional, social, and institutional responsibilities of working scientists. Develops critical skills for understanding and evaluating arguments, claims, and policies pertaining to moral, political, legal, and social aspects of research.

subject: Medical Humanities
description: Introduction to the major theories in contemporary bioethics and the application of these theories to current and standard questions in medical ethics.

subject: Medical Humanities
course_name: Application of Bioethics in Clinical Settings
description: P: HUMS 7100  or consent of instructor.      Practice based application of the core principles of bioethics in the clinical setting.

subject: Medical Humanities
description: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 s.h. with change of topic. P: Consent of instructor.      Independent exploration and scholarship of area(s) of interest in clinical bioethics.

subject: Medieval and Renaissance Studies
description: P: 3 s.h. in MRST or consent of director.      Interdisciplinary seminar.

subject: Metal Design
description: P: For undergraduate students: ART 2300 or consent of instructor.      Original research in metal design.

subject: Metal Design
description: P: For undergraduate students: ART 2300 or consent of instructor.      Original research in metal design.
