subject: Microbiology and Immunology
description: Mechanisms by which the immune system contributes to health and disease.

subject: Microbiology and Immunology
description: Mechanisms by which viruses replicate and influence health.

subject: Microbiology and Immunology
description: Mechanisms by which bacteria infect and influence the health of an individual.

subject: Microbiology and Immunology
description: P: BIOC 7301  or equivalent; admission to a BSOM graduate program or consent of chair.      Basic concepts and principles of immunology, genetics, and virology as they pertain to medical microbiology and medicine. Introduction to cellular and humoral aspects of the immune system and to mechanisms of host resistance to infectious disease. Survey of medically important viruses. Emphasis on biochemical anatomy, mechanisms of pathogenesis, lab diagnosis, and methods of control and prevention of infection.

subject: Microbiology and Immunology
description: P: MCBI 7400  ; admission to a BSOM graduate program or consent of chair.      Basic principles of medical bacteriology, mycology, and parasitology. Emphasis on mechanisms of pathogenesis, methods of laboratory diagnosis, and methods of control and prevention of diseases caused by these organisms. Content includes anatomy, physiology and genetics of medically important species of bacteria, fungi, animal parasites, and lab exercises.

subject: Microbiology and Immunology
description: ANAT 7202    P: Admission to a BSOM graduate program or consent of course director.      Foundational cornerstone for students interested in a contemporary research career. Principles of modern molecular biology as applied to the study of cell structure and function. Includes fundamentals of molecular and cellular biology of both prokaryotes and eukaryotes, and techniques used to study these problems. Emphasis on critical analysis of experimental data and experimental basis of current knowledge of cellular processes.

subject: Microbiology and Immunology
course_name: Physiology and Ultrastructure of Microorganisms I
description: P: MCBI 7400  or consent of instructor.      Advanced topics in molecular genetics and biochemical and physical organization of prokaryotic organism. Focuses on relationships of structure to function, growth, and metabolism and genetic mechanisms that regulate these activities in environment. Offered in spring semester of odd-numbered years.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Clinical Practicum in Nurse Anesthesia III
description: 32 clinical hours per week.  P: Admission to the DNP nurse anesthesia specialty area or permission of the nurse anesthesia program director; NURS 8272  , NURS 8815  , NURS 8820  ;  C: NURS 8274  , NURS 8816  .    Application of didactic learning through preparation, planning, and implementation of general and regional anesthetics. Use of previously developed skills and progress from basic anesthesia management to administration of anesthesia for patients with complex medical histories and for advanced procedures. Procedural knowledge, including communication and interprofessional collaboration, is reinforced by simulation instruction. Journal articles and case reports are presented, critically analyzed and discussed in weekly clinical conferences and monthly department conferences. Specialty clinical rotations include cardiovascular, neurological, obstetrics, pediatrics, and regional anesthesia. Clinical rotations are continued through university designated break periods.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Clinical Practicum in Nurse Anesthesia IV
description: 32 clinical hours per week.  P: Admission to the DNP nurse anesthesia specialty area or permission of the nurse anesthesia program director; NURS 8274  , NURS 8816  , NURS 8821  ;  C: NURS 8277  , NURS 8818  , NURS 8824  .    Application of didactic learning through preparation, planning, and implementation of general and regional anesthetics. Use of previously developed skills and progress from basic anesthesia management to administration of anesthesia for patients with complex medical histories and for advanced procedures. Procedural knowledge, including communication and interprofessional collaboration, is reinforced by simulation instruction. Journal articles and case reports are presented, critically analyzed and discussed in weekly clinical conferences and monthly department conferences. Specialty clinical rotations include cardiovascular, neurological, obstetrics, pediatrics, and regional anesthesia. Clinical rotations are continued through university designated break periods.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Clinical Practicum in Nurse Anesthesia V
description: 32 clinical hours per week.  P: Admission to the DNP nurse anesthesia specialty area or permission of the nurse anesthesia program director; NURS 8274  , NURS 8816  , NURS 8821  , NURS 8274  , NURS 8824  ;  C: NURS 8818  , NURS 8822  , NURS 8277  .    Application of didactic learning through preparation, planning, and implementation of general and regional anesthetics. Use of previously developed skills and progress from basic anesthesia management to administration of anesthesia for patients with complex medical histories and for advanced procedures. Procedural knowledge, including communication and interprofessional collaboration, is reinforced by simulation instruction. Journal articles and case reports are presented, critically analyzed and discussed in weekly clinical conferences and monthly department conferences. Specialty clinical rotations include cardiovascular, neurological, obstetrics, pediatrics, and regional anesthesia. Clinical rotations are continued through university designated break periods.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Advanced Principles of Nurse Anesthesia IV
description: 2 lecture hours per week.  P: Admission to the DNP nurse anesthesia specialty area or permission of the nurse anesthesia program director; NURS 8816  , NURS 8821  , NURS 8274  ;  C: NURS 8277  , NURS 8818  , NURS 8822  .    In depth study of principles of anesthesia practice with focus on tenets of anesthesia care for increasingly advanced surgical and radiological procedures on patients across the lifespan with complex medical histories, and acute and chronic pain.  Principles of safety and cultural sensitivity are incorporated throughout the course.

subject: Nursing
description: P: Admission to the DNP nurse anesthesia specialty area or permission of the nurse anesthesia program director; NURS 8277  , NURS 8818  , NURS 8822  , NURS 8824  ;  C: NURS 8812  , NURS 8823  .    Review, synthesis, and evaluation of entry level anesthesia knowledge. Demonstration of achievement program outcomes objectives through the creation of a professional portfolio that provides analysis of personal and professional growth and reflection on achievement in relation to program outcome objectives.

subject: Nursing
description: May be repeated. Minimum of 6 s.h. required; maximum of 12 s.h. may count. P: Successful completion of candidacy examination.      Original research investigation on a significant aspect of nursing science.

subject: Nursing
description: May be repeated. No credit may count toward degree. Students conducting dissertation research may only register for this course during the summer.

subject: Occupational Therapy
description: 4 classroom hours per week.  P: Admission to MS OT program or consent of graduate program director.      Foundations and models of practice of OT. Dimensions and characteristics of human occupation and their relationship to models of practice. Analysis of occupation, including real and symbolic aspects meaningful for individuals and populations.

subject: Occupational Therapy
description: 4 classroom hours per week.  P: Admission to MS OT program or consent of graduate program director.      Musculoskeletal system as related to human occupation. Mobility, stability, posture, biomechanics, development of movement, relationship between kinesiological components, and gradation of activities.

subject: Occupational Therapy
description: 3 lab hours per week.  P: Admission to MS OT program or consent of graduate program director.      Musculoskeletal system as related to human occupation. Mobility, stability, posture, biomechanics, development of movement, relationship between kinesiological components, and gradation of activities.

subject: Occupational Therapy
course_name: Dyadic and Group Skills in Occupational Therapy
description: 3 classroom hours per week.  P: Admission to MS OT program or consent of graduate program director.      Applies systems theory, communication, and techniques to dyadic and group processes relevant to OT. Relationships and roles of OT practice with individuals across life span.

subject: Occupational Therapy
course_name: Dyadic and Group Skills in Occupational Therapy Laboratory
description: 3 lab hours per week.  P: Admission to MS OT program or consent of graduate program director.      Applies systems theory, communication, and techniques to dyadic and group processes relevant to OT. Relationships and roles of OT practice with individuals across life span.

subject: Occupational Therapy
course_name: Health Impairments and Occupational Therapy I
description: 3 classroom hours per week.  P: Admission to MS OT program or consent of graduate program director.      Etiology of impairments and models of ablement/disablement. Identification of consequences of diseases, injuries or disorders and impact of these on human occupation. Applies appropriate OT frames of reference and remedial techniques.

subject: Occupational Therapy
course_name: Health Impairments and Occupational Therapy I Laboratory
description: 3 lab hours per week.  P: Admission to MS OT program or consent of graduate program director.      Etiology of impairments and models of ablement/disablement. Identification of consequences of diseases, injuries or disorders and impact of these on human occupation. Applies appropriate OT frames of reference and remedial techniques.

subject: Occupational Therapy
course_name: Health Impairments and Occupational Therapy II
description: 3 classroom hours per week.  P: Admission to MS OT program or consent of graduate program director.      Continuation of OCCT 6005  , OCCT 6006  .

subject: Occupational Therapy
course_name: Health Impairments and Occupational Therapy II Laboratory
description: 3 lab hours per week.  P: Admission to MS OT program or consent of graduate program director.      Continuation of OCCT 6005  , OCCT 6006  .

subject: Occupational Therapy
description: 3 classroom hours per week.  P: Admission to MS OT program or consent of graduate program director.      Occupational performance as affected by human nervous system. Structures and functions of human nervous system and relationship of occupation to brain function.

subject: Occupational Therapy
description: P: Admission to an occupational therapy graduate program or consent of graduate program coordinator/director.      The study of analysis and assessment of human anatomy, musculoskeletal system and movement related to occupation. Focuses on structures and functions of human musculoskeletal system and relationships between human musculoskeletal system and occupation.

subject: Occupational Therapy
description: 3 lab hours per week are required.  P: Admission to an occupational therapy graduate program or consent of graduate program coordinator/director;  C: OCCT 6011  .    The synthesis, application, and problem-solving of the knowledge of human anatomy and the musculoskeletal system in relation to movement and function. Focuses on the hands-on experience and clinical application of the knowledge of structures and functions of human musculoskeletal system and relationships between human musculoskeletal system and occupation.

subject: Occupational Therapy
description: P: Admission to an occupational therapy graduate program or consent of graduate program coordinator/director.      The study and analysis of the human nervous system. Focuses on structures and functions of the brain and human nervous system and relationship to occupation.

subject: Occupational Therapy
description: P: Admission to an occupational therapy graduate program or consent of graduate program coordinator/director.      The study of foundations of occupational therapy practice. Focuses on the domain and process of occupational therapy, dimensions and characteristics of human occupation, analysis of activity and occupation, theories, philosophy, and domains related to occupational therapy practice. Focuses on the theories and philosophy in relation to the major elements of occupational therapy practice, such as occupation, client, and therapist in the contexts of past, present, and future practice.

subject: Occupational Therapy
course_name: Leading and Managing Occupational Therapy Services
description: P: Admission to an occupational therapy graduate program or consent of graduate program coordinator/director.      The study of  management and leadership development and application in occupational therapy. Focuses on management roles and responsibilities and how those constructs impact the delivery, development, and advocacy of occupational therapy services in a variety of settings. Leadership theories are introduced and discussed in relation to effective management practices.

subject: Occupational Therapy
course_name: Leading and Managing Occupational Therapy Services Laboratory
description: 3 lab hours per week are required.  P: Admission to an occupational therapy graduate program or consent of graduate program coordinator/director.      The examination and application of management concepts necessary for  program development, service delivery, and new business implementation across a variety of settings for various populations.

subject: Occupational Therapy
course_name: Theoretical Models of Practice in Occupational Therapy
description: P: Enrollment in OCCT or consent of chair.      Advanced examination and conceptualization of OT theories within models of practice, including consultation. Analysis and comparison of theories applied to areas of specialty in service delivery systems.

subject: Occupational Therapy
description: Requires approval by occupational therapy advisor and/or graduate committee. May be repeated more than once with change of topic.       Individualized, advanced, or in-depth study of topic not offered in OT curriculum.

subject: Occupational Therapy
description: May be repeated more than once with change of topic.       Topics of current importance not covered thoroughly in other courses.

subject: Occupational Therapy
course_name: Environmental Contexts and Systems of Occupational Therapy
description: 3 classroom hours per week.  P: Admission to MS OT program or consent of graduate program director.      Systems analysis of societal, cultural, physical, and temporal environments. Evaluates use of environment and technology to enhance occupational function.

subject: Occupational Therapy
course_name: Therapeutic Use of Human Occupation I
description: 4 classroom hours per week.  P: Admission to MS OT program or consent of graduate program director.      First in three course sequence. Reflects a variety of system-practice contexts such as medical, educational, and natural environments. Occupational therapy roles, responsibilities, and interventions in the different settings will be examined.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Advanced Neonatal Nursing: Research and Theory II
description: May be repeated upon readmission to the concentration.   P: NURS 6420  .      Focuses on the integration of theoretical frameworks and evidence-based research into clinical decision-making, neonatal nurse practitioner management of disorders of organ systems, and care of the family unit.

subject: Nursing
description: May be repeated upon readmission to the concentration.     P/C: NURS 6422  .  Expands intensive neonatal clinical and didactic experiences by focusing on acute and chronic physiologic monitoring, diagnostic reasoning, anticipatory planning, and evidence-based therapeutic strategies in the daily management and follow-up care of the high-risk neonate and family.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Advanced Neonatal Nursing: Research and Theory III
description: May be repeated upon readmission to the concentration.  P: NURS 6422  .      Focuses on the collaborative integration of advanced knowledge to care for the infant and the family with complex needs.

subject: Nursing
description: May be repeated upon readmission to the concentration.     P/C: NURS 6424  .  Provides intensive neonatal clinical experiences for neonatal nurse practitioner students based on the knowledge and skills learned in previous courses under the direct supervision of on-site clinical preceptors.

subject: Nursing
description: May be repeated for a maximum of 9 s.h. P: Consent of advisor.      Nontraditional, faculty-approved projects relating to clinical and functional areas of study.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Health Assessment for Advanced Nursing Practice
description: P: Admission to NURS graduate program or consent of instructor.      Advanced assessment, critical thinking, and decision-making skills essential to evaluation of health status, health risks, illnesses, and functional/dysfunctional health patterns of individuals and family members throughout life span.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Clinical Pharmacology for Advanced Nursing Practice
description: P: Graduate status; admission to a graduate nursing program; or consent of concentration director.       In-depth presentation of pharmacologic principles to manage pharmacologic agents safely and effectively. Specialty labs address specific applications.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Advanced Pharmacology for Nurse Anesthesia I
description: P: Admission to nurse anesthesia concentration;  C: NURS 6813  .    Survey of pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics, adverse effects and pharmacotherapeutic principles of anesthesia, antimicrobial, antieoplastic, endocrine, and other therapeutic agents.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Advanced Pharmacology for Nurse Anesthetists II
description: P: NURS 6814  , NURS 6817  ;  C: NURS 6811  , NURS 6819  .    Surveys pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics, adverse effects, and pharmacotherapeutic principles of drugs affecting the autonomic, cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, and central nervous systems.

subject: Nursing
description: P: Admission to nurse anesthesia concentration;  C: NURS 6805  , NURS 6813  .    In-depth analysis of normal processes across the lifespan. Provides physiological basis for practice with emphasis on correlation of these concepts with clinical manifestations.

subject: Nursing
description: May be repeated upon readmission to the concentration.  P: NURS 6814  , NURS 6817  ; PTHE 7002;  C: NURS 6806  .    Chemical and physical principles involved in administration of anesthesia, including uptake and distribution, and toxicology of anesthetic drugs and agents.

subject: Nursing
description: P: NURS 6822  , NURS 6824  ;  C: NURS 6823  .    Historic, legal, ethical, and international issues important to contemporary nurse anesthesia practice.

subject: Nursing
description: P: Admission to nurse anesthesia concentration;  C: NURS 6805  .    Aspects of chemistry, biochemistry, and physics applicable to human and mechanical systems involved in delivering safe anesthesia care.

subject: Nursing
description: May be repeated upon readmission to the concentration.  P: Admission to nurse anesthesia concentration; NURS 6805  , NURS 6810  ;  C: NURS 6717; PTHE 7002.    Fundamentals of anesthesia practice, including basic techniques, procedures for administering anesthesia, assessment of patient status, and case management.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Advanced Principles of Nurse Anesthesia I
description: May be repeated upon readmission to the concentration.  P: Admission to nurse anesthesia concentration; NURS 6806  , NURS 6811  , NURS 6819  ;  C: NURS 6820  .    Anesthesia concepts for increasingly complex patients with alterations in one or more organ system. Includes principles of increasingly advanced surgical and radiological procedures.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Advanced Principles of Nurse Anesthesia II
description: P: Admission to nurse anesthesia concentration; NURS 6815  , NURS 6820  ;  C: NURS 6818  , NURS 6821  .    Advanced principles of cardiothoracic and vascular anesthesia, infection control, trauma anesthesia, and management of the patient with acute and chronic endocrine disease.

subject: Nursing
description: P: Admission to nurse anesthesia concentration; NURS 6805  , NURS 6810  , NURS 6813  ;  C: NURS 6814  ; PTHE 7002.    Links anesthesia-related information with specific topics in anatomy. Explores regional anesthesia.

subject: Nursing
description: P: Admission to the nurse anesthesia concentration; NURS 6815  , NURS 6820  .      Links research and advanced principles courses examining research in obstetrics, pediatrics, cardiothoracic and neurosurgical anesthesia.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Clinical Practicum in Nurse Anesthesia I
description: May be repeated upon readmission to the concentration.  P: Admission to nurse anesthesia concentration; NURS 6814  , NURS 6817  ;  C: NURS 6806  , NURS 6811  .    Introduces clinical practice in operating room environment, including basic skills such as monitoring, preoperative assessment, positioning, induction agents, and sequence and airway management.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Clinical Practicum in Nurse Anesthesia II
description: May be repeated upon readmission to the concentration. P: Admission to nurse anesthesia concentration; NURS 6806  , ACCT 6819;  C: NURS 6815  .    Defines physiological, pharmacological, and biochemical concepts in beginning application of anesthesia principles.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Clinical Practicum in Nurse Anesthesia III
description: May be repeated upon readmission to the concentration.  P: Admission to nurse anesthesia concentration; NURS 6820  ;  C: NURS 6816  , NURS 6818  .    Explores physiological, pharmacological, and biochemical concepts in complex clinical application of anesthesia principles.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Clinical Practicum in Nurse Anesthesia IV
description: May be repeated upon readmission to the concentration.  P: Admission to nurse anesthesia concentration; NURS 6818  , NURS 6821  ;  C: NURS 6824  .    Advanced clinical applications regarding anesthetic preparation, anesthesia equipment setup, airway management, anesthetic management, patient monitoring, and regional anesthesia.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Clinical Practicum in Nurse Anesthesia V
description: May be repeated upon readmission to the concentration.  P: Admission to nurse anesthesia concentration; NURS 6822  ;  C: NURS 6812  .    Advanced clinical practice utilizing all anesthesia principles to provide independent responsibility for patient care.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Advanced Principles of Nurse Anesthesia III
description: May be repeated upon readmission to the concentration.  P: Admission to nurse anesthesia concentration; NURS 6816  , NURS 6818  , NURS 6821  ;  C: NURS 6822  .    Advanced concepts of anesthetic management. Emphasis on renal, endocrine, pediatric, and obstetric cases, regional anesthesia, and chronic pain management.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Advanced Evidence-Based Practice for the Clinical Nurse Specialist
description: P: NURS 6959  or consent of concentration director.      Focuses on the role clinical nurse specialists practice in facilitating evidence-based processes and associated outcomes in specialty settings.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Diagnostic Reasoning in the Acutely Ill Patient
description: C: NURS 6895  .    Builds upon the foundational knowledge of physical assessment, pharmacology, and pathophysiology to refine techniques of history-taking, physical examination, and diagnostics in the acute care setting. Students develop clinical reasoning to care for the acutely ill adult and geriatric population through advanced clinical assessment, the development of differential diagnoses, and the creation of appropriate evidence-based interventions rooted in clinical reasoning.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Nurse Practitioner Roles in Acute Healthcare Settings
description: P: NURS 6893  ; RP: NURS 6895  , NURS 6896  , NURS 6897  ; C: NURS 6898  .     Examines the interrelated constructs of evidence-based practice, ethics, advocacy, policy, and legal principles employed by the nurse practitioner in acute care settings.

subject: Nursing
description: C: NURS 6893  .    Explores foundational knowledge needed for nurse practitioners to develop culturally competent, evidence-based clinical knowledge, skills, and diagnostic reasoning used in the assessment and management of common disorders in adults and geriatric patients in the acute care setting.

subject: Nursing
description: C: NURS 6897  .    Builds upon NURS 6895 to expand the foundation for nurse practitioners in developing culturally competent, evidence-based clinical knowledge, skills, and diagnostic reasoning used in the assessment and management of complex disorders in adults and geriatric patients in the acute care setting.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Introduction to Acute Care Practicum I
description: Students work under the direct supervision of an on-site clinical preceptor. P: NURS 6893  , NURS 6895  ;  C: NURS 6896  .    This initial clinical course focuses on the management of adult and geriatric patients experiencing common health problems across diverse acute care settings. Emphasis is on the clinical application of theoretical knowledge and shared decision-making skills using evidence-based practice.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Advanced Care of Acutely Ill Adults Practicum II
description: Students will work with the direct supervision of an on-site clinical preceptor.  P: NURS 6893  , NURS 6895  , NURS 6896  , NURS 6897  ;  C: NURS 6894  .    This second of three clinical courses focuses on the clinical management of adult and geriatric patients with increasingly complex health problems across diverse acute care settings. Emphasis is on the clinical application of theoretical knowledge and shared decision-making skills using evidence-based practice.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Acute Care Nurse Practitioner Clinical Competency Practicum III
description: Students will work under the direct supervision of an on-site clinical preceptor. P: NURS 6893  , NURS 6894  , NURS 6895  , NURS 6896  , NURS 6897  , NURS 6898  .      The third of three clinical courses establishes clinical competency in caring for adult and geriatric patients who are experiencing critical and complex healthcare disorders. Emphasis is on the clinical application of evidence-based, culturally competent care and shared decision-making with patients in acute, critical, and long-term acute care settings.

subject: Nursing
description: May be repeated upon readmission to the concentration.        Foundations, principles, and contemporary issues related to curriculum development in nursing education.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Educational Concepts, Theories, and Strategies in Nursing
description: May be repeated upon readmission to the concentration.      P/C: NURS 6903  or consent of instructor.  Explores learning theories and educational strategies used by nurse educators.

subject: Nursing
description: May be repeated upon readmission to the concentration. P: NURS 6909  or consent of instructor.      Guided practicum with nurse educators in academic and health care settings.

subject: Nursing
description: May be repeated upon readmission to the concentration.  P: NURS 6905  or consent of instructor.      Collaborative implementation and evaluation of comprehensive educational project.

subject: Nursing
description: May be repeated upon readmission to the concentration. P: NURS 6904  or consent of instructor.      Methods and models of evaluation for students, faculty, curricula, and programs.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Diagnostic Reasoning and Clinical Nurse Specialist Advanced Practice Management
description: RP/C: NURS 6050  , NURS 6611  . Focuses on the integration of advanced pharmacology, pathophysiology, and assessment for the clinical nurse specialist through a focus on formulation of differential diagnosis and development of plans of care that include pharmacologic and nonpharmacologic therapies.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Acute and Chronic Concerns for the Adult-Gerontology Clinical Nurse Specialist
description: Focuses on knowledge, theory, and management relevant to adult gerontology clients experiencing acute and chronic health concerns.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Clinical Nurse Specialist Theory and Role Development
description: May be repeated upon readmission to the concentration. P: NURS 6080  or NURS 6081  ; NURS 6050  or NURS 6610  or NURS 6208  .      Focuses on core competencies and theoretical models guiding clinical nurse specialist practice, including role development and implementation in complex health systems.

subject: Nursing
description: May be repeated upon readmission to the concentration. P: NURS 6959  , NURS 6889  .         Application of clinical nurse specialist (CNS) knowledge and skills to specialty clinical practice. Students gain skill in achieving effective patient outcomes, improving nursing practice and influencing organizational systems.

subject: Nursing
description: May be repeated upon readmission to the concentration. P: NURS 6960  .      Application of clinical nurse specialist (CNS) knowledge and skills to specialty clinical practice. Students gain skill in achieving effective patient outcomes, improving nursing practice and influencing organizational systems.

subject: Nursing
description: May be repeated upon readmission to the concentration. P: NURS 6961  .      Application of clinical nurse specialist (CNS) knowledge and skills to specialty clinical practice. Students gain skill in achieving effective patient outcomes, improving nursing practice and influencing organizational systems.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Health Policy, Law, and Ethical Decision Making
description: P: Consent of program director.       An overview of health policy, law and ethical decision making as they relate to the leadership of health care delivery in the United States.

subject: Nursing
description: P/C: Consent of program director.  Focuses on the practical dimensions of human relations in health systems. Explores current trends and strategies for managing employees including recruitment and retention.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Financial Management and Decision-Making in Nursing Leadership
description: P/C: Consent of program director.  Focuses on the practical application of financial concepts in executing nursing decisions in various healthcare settings. Content-based on the Institute for Healthcare Improvement (IHI) Triple AIM philosophy of improving the patient experience of care (quality and satisfaction), improving the health of populations, and reducing the per capita cost of healthcare; thus, resulting in quality improvement/patient safety and positive clinical outcomes in current health system.

subject: Nursing
description: 9 hours per week for class / 126 clinical contact hours May be repeated upon readmission to the concentration.     P/C: NURS 6983  or consent of program director.  Application of organizational and administrative theory, ethics, and clinical service and outcome management concepts within nursing and health systems.

subject: Nursing
description: 9 hours per week for class / 126 clinical contact hours (2.5: 1 ratio) May be repeated upon readmission to the concentration.     P/C: NURS 6977  or consent of program director.  Application of organizational and administrative theory within nursing and health systems in a selected focus area.

subject: Nursing
course_name: Theoretical and Operational Perspectives for Systems Leadership
description: P/C: NURS 6080  , NURS 6081  ; or consent of program director.  Examines organizational, administrative, and ethical theory that relate to the leadership of nursing and health systems.

subject: Nursing
description: Application of informatics systems to practice, research, education, and administration of nursing.
